St Mary’s House Dental Care is a long-established private practice in Shoreham-by-Sea. We focus on careful planning, calm delivery, and dentistry that makes sense for the long term.

We look after everyday oral health and also support complex cases involving tooth wear, missing teeth, implant-supported restorations, heavily restored mouths, and bite-related problems.

Appointments are structured so you understand what we’ve found, what it means, and what your realistic options are. If you’re anxious, short on time, or simply want things explained properly, we’ll take a measured approach and agree the next step together.
Dentistry designed for clarity, comfort, and long-term confidence

Care at St Mary’s House is built around time, explanation, and respect for every patient’s circumstances.

We provide general, restorative, implant, orthodontic, and aesthetic dentistry, but we don’t rush decisions or push treatment. Appointments are unhurried, explanations are clear, and choices are made collaboratively.
Over 30 years of experience across restorative and orthodontic care.
Advanced restorative and orthodontic training applied to complex cases.
CBCT-guided implant planning for precise placement and healing.
In-house digital dentistry to shorten feedback loops and keep planning clear.
Care that values planning as much as precision

Good dentistry isn’t just about a single procedure. It’s about understanding bite, function, health, aesthetics, and long-term stability — and planning accordingly.

We take a conservative, evidence-led approach. When care becomes complex or irreversible — implants, extractions, root canal treatment, veneers, larger restorative plans — we slow things down, map out options clearly, and proceed step by step with your comfort and understanding at the centre.
Composite bonding, veneers, and full smile refinement
Clear aligners with mapped movement and check-ins
Implant dentistry, whitening, and restorative care
Share goals and capture scans for a precise baseline
Preview options with visual planning and simple language
Start treatment with clear timelines and follow-ups

Many patients come to us after years of piecemeal dentistry, unresolved problems, or uncertainty about what should happen next. These cases need structure, not speed.

Our approach brings disciplines together — restorative, orthodontic, implant, and digital planning — so treatment is sequenced sensibly and reviewed carefully. For missing teeth, that may include implant-supported restorations or implant-retained dentures, planned with stability, comfort, and ease of maintenance in mind.

The aim is a clearer path forward before anything irreversible begins.

Established care for Shoreham-by-Sea and surrounding communities

We’ve cared for patients from Shoreham-by-Sea and surrounding towns for many years. Many stay with us long-term — not because they need ongoing treatment, but because they value consistency and knowing who is looking after them.

Dentistry works best when your dentist understands your history, priorities, and concerns. That continuity matters whether you’re visiting for routine care, managing dental wear over time, or planning something more involved.
A long-established Shoreham-by-Sea dental practice for patients who value experience, continuity, and well-planned care.
Practice: St Mary’s House Dental Care, Shoreham-by-Sea
Address area: Central Shoreham-by-Sea near the River Adur
Phone: Reach the team through the contact page for a call-back

St Mary’s House Dental Care is located in Shoreham-by-Sea and is easy to reach from Lancing, Southwick, Worthing, and Brighton.

Clear directions and parking information are available, and you can open our location directly in Google Maps if you’re planning your visit.

If you need directions or parking information, just ask — our reception team can advise.

I’m nervous about dental treatment. Is that a problem?

Not at all. Many people feel anxious about dental visits, and we’re used to working at a pace that feels comfortable. We explain what’s happening before we do anything, check in as we go, and adjust if you need a pause.

Comfort is always taken seriously. Local anaesthetic is used when needed, and nothing is rushed. Most patients are surprised by how manageable treatment feels when things are explained clearly and done at a measured pace.
Do I have to decide on treatment straight away?
No. In many cases, the first appointment is about understanding what’s going on and discussing options. You’re never expected to decide on the spot.
Do you do implants and complex restorative work?
Yes. We place and restore implants and also help patients who already have implants. Where treatment is complex or irreversible, planning and explanation come first so decisions are made carefully.
What if I just want advice or a second opinion?
That’s fine. Some patients come to us simply to understand their situation better before deciding what to do next. We’re happy to help with that.
Yes. Many of our patients are older and value a calmer, more considered approach. Continuity, explanation, and comfort are especially important in long-term care.
Do you help with directions or parking?
Yes — call or message ahead and we can outline nearby parking options and the easiest way to enter the practice.
Can I start with a phone discussion?
You can request a call-back through the contact page to discuss your goals before booking a visit.
Do you see patients from nearby towns?
We regularly welcome patients from Shoreham-by-Sea, Lancing, Worthing, Southwick, Hove, and Brighton.
Is the practice suitable for nervous patients?
Yes—gentle pacing, clear numbing options, and calm explanations are part of every visit.

Your first visit is about listening, understanding your concerns, and gathering the information needed to guide you properly. You don’t need to know where to start. We’ll take things step by step.

Where treatment is required, options are explained clearly, including benefits, limitations, costs, and timescales. From there, you can decide how — or whether — to proceed, with support available at every stage.

Missing teeth can change how you eat, speak and smile — and it’s not always obvious what the “right” solution is. At St Mary’s House Dental Care, implant care is clinician-led and planning-heavy: we focus on getting the foundations right so you can make a confident decision.

We’ll talk you through options (implants, bridges, dentures — or sometimes “do nothing yet”), explain the trade-offs, and recommend what’s sensible for your mouth, your health, and your long-term maintenance.
Fixed tooth replacement for suitable patients
Clear options and costs explained upfront
Local care in Shoreham-by-Sea, near Brighton
Clinician-led, planning-first — We prioritise diagnosis, stability and long-term maintenance, not rushed sales dentistry.
Digital assessment where appropriate — Scans and 3D planning can help us assess bone, bite and space, and reduce uncertainty.
Guided surgery where appropriate — When suitable, we design and 3D print surgical guides to help transfer the plan accurately to the mouth.
Clear, transparent care — We explain benefits, risks and alternatives, and give you time to decide.
Local follow-up and aftercare — Implant health is a long game, and reviews plus hygiene support matter.

Dental implants can be a suitable option for many people — but they are not a “one size fits all” treatment. Outcomes depend on bone levels, gum health, bite forces, space, and the position of neighbouring teeth.

Our approach is to plan the tooth first and the implant second. Where appropriate, we use 3D imaging and digital planning to choose implant position and angulation that supports a cleanable, well-supported final crown.
Design for cleaning and long-term gum health
Consider bite forces, not just appearance

A dental implant is a small post placed into the jawbone to act as a replacement tooth root. Once healed, it supports a restoration — commonly a crown for a single tooth, or a bridge or denture solution for multiple teeth.

Implant treatment is usually staged and depends on healing. We’ll explain what’s involved and what alternatives might suit you better.
When implants can be a good option — If you have one or more missing teeth and want a fixed solution, implants may be suitable after assessment.
Bone and gum health matters — Healthy gums and adequate bone are important. If bone is reduced, grafting may sometimes be considered.
Medical factors — Some medical conditions and medications can affect healing. We’ll take a full history and advise safely.
Smoking and maintenance — Smoking and inconsistent cleaning can increase risk. We’ll be honest about what improves success.
Alternatives are sometimes better — In some mouths, a bridge, denture, or a short period of monitoring may be the better choice.
1) Consultation & assessment — We examine your teeth and gums, discuss your goals, and check suitability. Scans may be advised.
2) Planning — If proceeding, we plan tooth position, implant placement and timings. You’ll receive a clear treatment outline.
3) Implant placement — The implant is placed under local anaesthetic (and sedation options may be discussed where appropriate).
4) Healing phase — Healing time varies. We’ll guide you on what to expect and how to look after the area.
5) Final restoration — Once stable, we fit the crown or bridge and check bite, appearance and cleanability.
6) Reviews & maintenance — Long-term health depends on cleaning and regular reviews — we’ll support you with both.
Timelines vary. Healing time, bone quality, and your medical history guide whether we stage treatment or move more quickly.
Digital and 3D dentistry for implant care

Where appropriate, we use digital scans and 3D planning to assess space, bone and bite, and to design implant placement with the final tooth in mind. We also design and 3D print surgical guides to help position implants accurately according to the plan.

Digital tools don’t replace clinical judgement — but used well, they can reduce uncertainty and improve communication.
Fixed, natural feel — Implants can feel closer to natural teeth than removable options, for suitable cases.
No need to prepare neighbouring teeth — A single implant crown doesn’t usually require shaping adjacent teeth (unlike some bridge designs).
Supports bone and function — Replacing a missing root can help maintain function; we’ll explain what’s realistic for your case.
Designed for cleaning — We plan restorations to be maintainable, because “looks great” isn’t enough without long-term health.
Clear, honest planning — We explain risks, alternatives, and maintenance so you can decide with confidence.
Cleaning is non-negotiable — Implants need daily cleaning just like teeth, sometimes with specific brushes or interdental aids.
Regular reviews — We monitor gums, bite and implant stability over time and act early if anything changes.
Hygiene support — Professional cleaning and coaching can protect long-term implant health.
Lifestyle factors — Smoking and uncontrolled gum disease increase risk — we’ll help you reduce avoidable problems.
Are dental implants right for everyone?
Not always. Suitability depends on gum health, bone levels, bite forces, medical history and maintenance. We confirm this after assessment.
Implant placement is usually done with local anaesthetic. Most people describe post-treatment soreness rather than “pain”. We’ll explain what to expect and how we manage comfort.
Timings vary. Some cases need staged healing or additional procedures. We’ll give you a realistic timeline once we’ve assessed you.
Many implants function well for a long time, but outcomes depend on factors like cleaning, gum health, smoking, bite forces and general health. We’ll discuss risks and maintenance honestly.
What if I don’t have enough bone?
Reduced bone doesn’t automatically rule implants out. In some cases, bone grafting may be considered. We’ll explain whether it’s appropriate and the trade-offs.
What are the alternatives to implants?
Depending on your mouth, options may include bridges, dentures, or sometimes doing nothing for a period. We’ll compare pros and cons so you can choose confidently.
Costs depend on complexity and the type of restoration. After assessment, we’ll provide clear options and fees so you can decide without pressure.
Implant care at St Mary’s House — clinician-led

Dr Nick Maxwell leads implant planning and placement at St Mary’s House Dental Care. He holds an MSc in Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry and a PGDip in Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics, and has completed implant surgical training including intensive implant placement training in Cairo (2014).

He also designs and 3D prints surgical guides for guided implant placement, combining clinical judgement with digital planning where appropriate. The focus is careful case selection, clear communication, and long-term maintainability.
Implant planning and placement led by Dr Nick Maxwell
MSc in Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry with a PGDip in Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics
Implant surgical training including intensive placement training in Cairo (2014)
Guided surgery supported by in-house 3D planning and printed guides

Implants can be a suitable solution — but the right choice depends on your priorities: fixed versus removable options, speed versus staged healing, and what can be maintained long-term.

At your assessment we’ll answer three practical questions:
Are implants sensible and safe in your mouth?
What are the realistic options (and alternatives)?
What would we recommend if you were family?
No pressure, no hype — just a clear plan you can understand.
If you’re considering implants, we’ll assess suitability, explain options and costs, and help you decide with confidence.

Veneers are thin restorations placed on the front surface of teeth to refine shape, colour and alignment. They can be an excellent option when the teeth underneath are healthy enough, and when the plan is conservative and carefully staged. We start by understanding what you’d like to change, then assess enamel, bite, gum health and wear patterns so the result is stable and maintainable. In many cases, we can explore minimal-prep or additive approaches, or consider alternatives such as whitening, bonding, or aligners first. If veneers are suitable, we’ll talk through preview options, longevity factors and how to protect the finished work.
Natural-looking smiles tailored to your face
Digital smile planning to preview outcomes

Porcelain and composite veneers with measured preparation

Veneers are thin restorations that refine shape, shade, and symmetry. Porcelain veneers are made in the lab for strength and longevity; composite veneers are crafted directly and can be adjusted over time. We keep claims conservative and only recommend veneers when they are the safest option for your teeth.
Lab-made porcelain veneers for durability and refined translucency
Composite veneers sculpted chairside with the option to revise
Minimal-prep or no-prep approaches considered when enamel allows

Not suitable for everyone — habits like grinding or nail biting are reviewed first

Porcelain veneers vs digitally designed / 3D printed veneers
Choosing between ceramic longevity and staged printed options
Longevity: porcelain is engineered for long-term wear; digitally designed or 3D printed veneers suit staged plans or shorter horizons.
Cost: printed options are more affordable upfront; porcelain reflects laboratory artistry and durability.
Repairability: printed and composite-style veneers can be repaired or refreshed; porcelain often needs replacement if a major chip occurs.
Thickness: porcelain can be ultra-thin yet strong; printed options are conservative but may need a little more thickness for stability.
Aesthetic ceiling: porcelain offers the highest translucency, texture, and colour layering; printed veneers provide a natural upgrade with a modest sheen.
Best suited: porcelain for long-term, high-demand smiles; printed for previews, budget-conscious stages, or when a full smile makeover is still being planned (/treatments/full-smile-makeover).
Laboratory porcelain and regulated printed resins

Porcelain veneers are hand-layered in the lab with staining, characterisation, and glazing that suit your neighbouring teeth. Printed or milled options use FDA-cleared and CE-marked resins, then are hand finished chairside for gum harmony, bite integration, and a natural sheen.
Short-term sensitivity can occur after preparation or fitting
Chipping or debonding is possible — we plan bite to reduce stress
Composite can stain over time; polishing or refreshes may be advised
Gums may need a settling period around new margins
Bite or speech may feel different initially; adjustments are available
Night guards or retainers recommended if grinding or previous orthodontics are factors
Regular reviews and hygiene visits support long-term stability
Clear boundaries so results stay predictable
Veneers are not maintenance-free — hygiene visits and home care protect the margins and gumline.
Chipping, wear, or staining can happen, especially with strong bite forces or frequent dark foods and drinks.
Night guards are advised for clenching or grinding to protect edges and adhesive bonds.
Printed veneers are a more affordable step but not a lifetime solution; we set expectations for refresh or porcelain upgrades.

We review when whitening, composite bonding, or a full smile makeover may be safer alternatives for your goals (/treatments/teeth-whitening, /treatments/composite-bonding, /treatments/full-smile-makeover).

Longevity depends on material, bite forces, and maintenance. Porcelain can offer many stable years with night guard protection and reviews; digitally designed or composite-style veneers may need refreshes or upgrades sooner.

Costs vary by material and complexity. Printed or composite-style options are the most affordable, while handcrafted porcelain reflects lab artistry and longevity. We outline options and payment plans before you commit.

Suitability depends on gum health, enamel thickness, bite, and habits. We may recommend whitening, composite bonding, orthodontics, or a full smile makeover instead if coverage is not the safest choice.

Routine hygiene, non-abrasive home care, and wearing a night guard if you clench all extend veneer life. Printed or composite-style veneers may need more frequent polishing or planned replacement; porcelain benefits from the same protective habits.

Clear aligners straighten teeth using a series of custom trays that move teeth in small, planned steps. The key is diagnosis and planning: we assess your bite, gum health, tooth wear and any jaw symptoms, then use digital scans to model movement and discuss what’s realistic. Aligners can help with crowding, spacing and some bite corrections, but not every case is suitable — and retention is essential to keep results stable. We’ll also discuss where aligners fit alongside whitening, bonding or restorative work, especially if you’re planning a broader smile refresh. If aligners are recommended, you’ll receive a clear timeline, check-in plan and aftercare guidance.
Plan a clinician-led clear aligners review

Clear aligners use a series of custom trays to guide teeth into position. Each stage is planned digitally, so you know the expected movements, check-in cadence, and how to care for trays day to day, with options to align shade through whitening (/treatments/teeth-whitening) or plan veneers (/treatments/veneers) once alignment is stable.

How much do clear aligners cost?
Fees depend on complexity and length of treatment; we outline a range after assessing your teeth and the expected number of stages.
How long will I wear aligners?
Most mild to moderate cases run for several months to over a year; we share a projected timeline and review it at each check-in.
You may feel pressure or mild soreness for a few days when switching trays; it typically eases with consistent wear.
Can I eat and drink with aligners in?
Remove aligners for meals and anything other than still water to avoid staining or warping the trays.
Small tooth-coloured bumps that help guide movement. We explain placement, visibility, and care before adding them.
Some patients notice a slight lisp for a few days. Speech usually settles as you adapt to the trays.
What if I lose an aligner?
Contact the clinic quickly. We’ll advise whether to move to the next tray, use a previous one, or order a replacement.
Do I need retainers after treatment?
Yes. Retainers hold your new tooth positions and reduce relapse risk. We’ll agree a wear schedule and maintenance plan.

Fixed braces move teeth using brackets and wires, offering a highly controlled way to correct alignment and bite problems. They can be a good choice where movements are more complex, where precise finishing is important, or where aligners are less suitable. We’ll assess gum health, enamel condition and bite forces before starting, then plan the sequence of movement and discuss expected timelines. During treatment, regular reviews allow adjustments to keep progress steady and safe. Retention is essential after braces, so we’ll explain retainers and long-term maintenance. If your goals include cosmetic refinements afterwards, we’ll help sequence whitening or bonding sensibly.

Our smile gallery shares examples of treatments carried out at St Mary’s House Dental Care, with the aim of helping you understand what different options can look like in real life. Every smile is unique and results vary, so these cases are here to support informed conversations — not to promise a specific outcome. Where we share before-and-after images, we do so with consent and with context about the type of work involved. If you see a result you like, we can discuss whether a similar approach is clinically suitable for you, and what the planning would involve.

Each case includes a brief summary of the starting point, the type of treatment provided, and the kind of planning involved.

Where before-and-after images are shown, they are there to help you understand what may be possible — not to suggest you will get an identical result. Photographs also don’t show everything that matters in dentistry, such as bite, gum health, long-term maintenance, or the stability of the underlying teeth.

If you see a style of outcome you like, we can talk through whether a similar approach is clinically suitable for you and what would need to be assessed first.
About St Mary’s House Dental Care

St Mary’s House Dental Care is a long-established private dental practice in Shoreham-by-Sea.

We work in a calm, clinician-led way: careful assessment, clear explanation, and treatment planned for long-term stability rather than quick fixes.

If you’re nervous about dentistry, or you’ve had mixed experiences in the past, we’ll take things at a pace that feels manageable and explain what we’re doing as we go.

How we work is simple, even if the dentistry isn’t.

We start with understanding the problem properly before talking about solutions. We explain options in plain English, including limits and trade-offs. Where it helps outcomes and costs, we plan treatment in stages. And we focus on comfort, fit, and long-term maintenance — not hype.

The practice has been part of the Shoreham area for many years, and the building itself reflects that history.

Dentistry has changed a lot over time, but the principles haven’t: careful diagnosis, sensible planning, and work you can live with comfortably. We continue to improve how we assess, plan, and deliver care, while keeping the experience calm and straightforward.
Part of Shoreham, not just located in it

Good dentistry should feel understandable and unrushed.

Whether you need a simple check-up or more involved restorative work, our job is to help you make clear decisions you’ll still feel comfortable with in five and ten years’ time.

Dentistry works best when it’s delivered by people who know each other well.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we’re a small, experienced team who work together every day — not a rotating cast. That continuity matters. It affects communication, planning, and how calmly care is delivered.

Patients often tell us they value recognising familiar faces and feeling understood rather than processed.

Good outcomes in dentistry depend on more than individual skill.

They rely on clear communication between clinicians and nurses, shared standards of care, and consistency in how patients are looked after. Our team works closely across examinations, hygiene, restorative care, and longer-term treatment planning.

That collaboration reduces errors, avoids duplication, and makes appointments feel more settled.
Principal dentist. Calm, planning-led care with a focus on long-term stability and clear explanation.
Associate dentist. Thoughtful, prevention-focused dentistry with a clear, reassuring approach.
Associate dentist. Practical, patient-centred care with attention to comfort, clarity, and sensible options.

Dental nurses and support staff play a central role in patient care.

They are often the first point of contact, the calm presence during treatment, and the continuity between visits. Many of our nurses have worked here for years and know patients well.

Dr Nick Maxwell
Principal Dentist · Restorative, Aesthetic & Digital Dentistry

I’m Dr Nick Maxwell, principal dentist at St Mary’s House Dental Care in Shoreham-by-Sea.
I’ve been practising dentistry since 1998 and have spent much of my career focused on the kind of dentistry that needs calm judgment: complex restorative work, aesthetic planning, bite stability, and carefully selected implant and orthodontic cases.
My aim is simple: help patients make decisions they can feel good about years from now — not just next month.

Qualifications and training

I hold:
• BDS (King’s College London)
• MSc Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry
• PGDip Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics
I’ve also completed implant surgical training and intensive implant placement training (Cairo, 2014).
Qualifications matter, but what matters most is what they change in day-to-day care: the ability to plan, select cases carefully, and avoid unnecessary intervention.

How I work

Dentistry can be rushed. It can also be over-sold. I’m not interested in either.
My approach is deliberately planning-first and case-by-case:
• We start with diagnosis and stability, not “what you’d like done”
• We talk honestly about trade-offs and limitations
• I’m happy to recommend the simplest sensible option — and equally happy to advise against treatment that isn’t in your long-term interest
That’s what I mean by “sleep-at-night dentistry”.

Digital dentistry and 3D planning

Over the past several years I’ve developed a strong focus on digital dentistry — not as a gimmick, but as a way to plan more precisely and communicate more clearly.
This includes:
• digital planning workflows for restorative and implant cases
• CBCT-based assessment where appropriate
• designing and 3D-printing surgical guides for guided implant placement
• a strong emphasis on predictability and maintainability
Technology doesn’t replace clinical judgment — but used properly, it helps reduce uncertainty and improves decision-making.

Patients often come to see me when they want a calm, honest second opinion, a long-term plan rather than a quick fix, and careful aesthetic work that still respects tooth structure. If you’re looking for rushed dentistry, I won’t be the right fit. If you want careful, clinician-led planning, you probably will.

Dr Sylvia Krafft is an Associate Dentist at St Mary’s House Dental Care in Shoreham-by-Sea. She qualified as a Zahnarzt (Dental Surgeon) at the University of Cologne and has over 20 years’ experience working in general dentistry across Germany, the United States and the United Kingdom.

Patients commonly see Dr Krafft for general dental care, prevention-focused treatment and aesthetic dentistry delivered with a conservative, minimally invasive approach. She has a particular interest in improving the appearance of teeth in ways that remain biologically sound and appropriate for long-term oral health.

Since relocating to the UK in 2009, Dr Krafft has worked extensively in both NHS and private practice. Her international background allows her to draw on a broad range of clinical perspectives, supporting thoughtful, individualised care for patients of all ages.

She is especially valued by patients who want careful explanations, realistic expectations and treatment that enhances confidence without unnecessary intervention.

Dr Krafft qualified as a Zahnarzt (Dental Surgeon) at the University of Cologne (Zahnklinik Köln) in 2001. In addition to her dental qualification, she is also a trained dental technician, giving her a detailed understanding of dental materials, morphology and precision.

Early in her career, she worked in general practice in Germany before moving to the United States, where she volunteered at a dental charity hospital in Miami. This experience reinforced her commitment to ethical, patient-centred care and to providing treatment that balances clinical need with individual circumstance.

Since moving to the UK in 2009, Dr Krafft has gained over 15 years’ experience across NHS and private dentistry. She has developed a particular interest in aesthetic dentistry delivered conservatively, focusing on proportion, harmony and tooth preservation rather than aggressive cosmetic change.

Her background as both clinician and technician informs a careful, detail-led approach, especially when planning aesthetic or restorative work. GDC: 174528.

Dr Krafft’s clinical approach is centred on prevention, minimal intervention and patient understanding. She believes that aesthetic dentistry should enhance natural features rather than replace them, and that successful outcomes depend on respecting the biology of teeth and gums.

She prioritises conservative solutions wherever possible and takes time to explain options clearly, including what can be achieved predictably and what may introduce unnecessary risk. Patients are encouraged to make informed decisions at a pace that feels comfortable, with realistic expectations set from the outset.

For patients who feel anxious, Dr Krafft focuses on building trust through calm communication and a supportive, unhurried approach. Treatment is adapted to individual comfort levels, and patients are kept fully informed and in control throughout their care.

Her dual training as a dentist and dental technician supports a precise, considered approach to both aesthetic and functional treatment. Long-term oral health, stability and maintainability are always prioritised over short-term cosmetic change.

Dr Krafft values dentistry for the balance it offers between technical precision and human connection. She enjoys helping patients feel more confident about their smile in a way that remains natural and sustainable, and takes particular satisfaction in supporting patients who appreciate careful, considered care rather than rushed solutions.

Sara Burden is a Dental Hygienist at St Mary’s House Dental Care, with over 30 years’ experience in dental hygiene. She qualified from Birmingham Dental School in 1990 and has worked across general practice, specialist care and research settings.

Patients commonly see Sara for periodontal care, maintenance appointments and support with gum health, particularly where long-term stability is essential. She is known for her gentle, thorough approach and for helping patients feel at ease, especially those who may feel anxious about hygiene treatment.

Sara plays an important role within the practice’s preventative and long-term care philosophy, working closely with the dentists to support restorative and implant treatment planning through ongoing periodontal health.

Sara qualified as a dental hygienist from Birmingham Dental School in 1990. Over the course of her career, she has gained extensive experience in general dental practice, specialist environments and dental research.

She has a particular interest in the management of acute gum conditions and in the relationship between oral health, nutrition and systemic wellbeing. Sara takes a holistic view of periodontal care, supporting patients with practical, evidence-based advice alongside clinical treatment.

She remains committed to maintaining high professional standards and keeps her knowledge up to date through regular continuing professional development, ensuring her approach reflects current best practice in periodontal care. GDC: 3966.

Sara’s approach to dental hygiene is preventative, methodical and patient-focused. She believes effective periodontal care relies on understanding, consistency and realistic guidance that patients can apply between visits.

She takes time to explain findings clearly, discuss contributing factors and demonstrate techniques where helpful, allowing patients to feel informed rather than overwhelmed. Appointments are unhurried and adapted to individual comfort levels, with particular consideration given to patients who may feel nervous or sensitive.

Sara places strong emphasis on long-term maintenance, recognising that stable gum health is essential for both natural teeth and restorative work. Her aim is to support predictable, sustainable oral health outcomes through collaborative care and clear communication.

Sara values the long-term relationships that develop through preventative care and enjoys supporting patients as their oral health improves over time. She takes particular satisfaction in helping people feel more comfortable, confident and informed about their gum health.

Dental fees vary because treatment depends on the condition of the teeth and gums, the complexity of care, and the time and materials required.

Two people having what sounds like the same treatment may need very different levels of care.

Because of this, we avoid giving fixed prices without first seeing you.

Before any treatment is started, we take time to understand what you actually need. This usually involves an examination, appropriate X-rays or scans, and a discussion about your priorities.

Where treatment is straightforward, fees can often be estimated quite accurately. For more complex or staged care, we will explain the likely range and the factors that could affect it.

You will always be given a written treatment plan before going ahead, and nothing is carried out without your agreement.

If you are unsure whether a particular treatment is appropriate, or simply want to understand likely costs before booking, please get in touch.

Initial conversations are about understanding your situation, not committing you to treatment.

Our fees are not just for the treatment you receive on the day. They reflect the full clinical process, which may include:

• detailed assessment and diagnosis
• digital imaging and planning where appropriate
• high-quality materials and laboratory work
• time for careful, unhurried delivery
• follow-up care and review

This approach supports safe, well-planned care that is tailored to you — not simply completed quickly.

Not all dental treatment needs to be done at once.

In many cases, care can be planned in stages, allowing you to prioritise what matters most and spread treatment over time. This approach often leads to better long-term outcomes and more manageable costs.

We are happy to talk through different options and help you decide what feels right for you.

Payment is usually taken at the time of treatment. For larger treatment plans, finance options may be available to help spread the cost.

If finance is something you would like to consider, we can explain how it works and whether it may be suitable for your situation.

We’ll always explain costs clearly before treatment starts, so you’re not faced with surprises.
Flexible plans to spread the cost of your care.

- You can browse and use this website for personal, lawful purposes.
- The information is general and may not apply to your specific situation.
- Dentistry often needs an examination and sometimes X-rays or scans before advice is reliable.
- If you need urgent help, please contact us rather than relying on website information.

You are welcome to print or share pages for personal use, but please don’t copy large parts of the site for commercial use.

If you’re making decisions about treatment, the safest route is always an appointment where we can assess you properly and explain options, limits, and likely maintenance.

If you have questions about the website content, or you believe something is unclear or out of date, please contact the practice and we’ll do our best to help.

For clinical concerns (pain, swelling, broken teeth, lost restorations, or anything urgent), please call us so we can guide you to the right next step.

We may update these website terms from time to time to reflect changes to the site or how we provide information.

The current version will always be available on this page.

We want our website to be usable for as many people as possible. Accessibility is an ongoing process, and we aim to improve readability, navigation, and compatibility with assistive technologies over time. If you find any part of the site difficult to use — for example, problems with contrast, text size, forms, or keyboard navigation — please let us know. Where possible, we can provide information in an alternative format and record feedback for future improvements.
We aim to make the website as usable as possible for as many people as possible. Accessibility is an ongoing process, and we review clarity, navigation and compatibility as the site evolves.
What you can do on your side
Many people improve readability using browser or device settings (text size, zoom, contrast modes, reader modes, and voice control). If you’d like help finding those settings, let us know.

Some third-party tools, embedded media, or older documents may not meet every accessibility standard in every situation. If you find something that isn’t working for you, we want to know so we can look at alternatives.
If you need information in a different format, we can usually provide it or talk it through. Contact the practice and tell us what would help.
We act on feedback where we reasonably can. This page may be updated as improvements are made.

If something hasn’t felt right, we want to know.

We take complaints seriously and we aim to resolve concerns fairly, calmly, and as quickly as possible.

If you feel able, please raise the issue with us directly first. Most concerns can be resolved promptly once we understand what has happened and what you’re worried about.

This page explains how to raise a concern or complaint about care you have received, and how we handle it.

It is not a substitute for clinical advice. If you have pain, swelling, trauma, or an urgent problem, please contact the practice so we can help you quickly.

- Tell us what happened and what outcome you’re hoping for.
- We will listen, review what we can, and respond clearly.
- If we need time to investigate properly, we will tell you the expected timescales.
- You can raise concerns in writing, by email, or by speaking to the team.

You can bring someone with you to support you if you prefer.

If you would like your complaint handled by a specific person, let us know and we will do our best to accommodate this, depending on availability and the nature of the concern.

We keep complaints confidential and handle them in line with professional and legal obligations.

The best first step is to contact the practice directly so we can understand the issue and try to resolve it.

If you prefer to put things in writing, email is often the clearest way to set out what happened and what you would like us to do next.

Dental check-ups are not just about teeth. They are an opportunity to assess your overall oral health, identify early changes, and discuss concerns before they become more complex.

As part of a routine examination, we also look for signs of oral cancer and other soft tissue conditions. These checks are visual and hands-on, and are carried out carefully at each visit.

For most people, nothing unusual is found. The value lies in consistency and familiarity — knowing what is normal for you, and noticing when something changes.
A dental check-up involves examining your teeth, gums, bite, and existing dental work.

We look for early signs of decay, gum disease, wear, or fracture, and assess how restorations are functioning over time. X-rays may be recommended where clinically justified to see areas that cannot be assessed visually.
Time is also set aside to discuss symptoms, habits, or changes you’ve noticed, so care can be tailored rather than routine.
Low-dose digital x-rays when clinically indicated
Intraoral photos to track changes and share progress

Most people stay on track with 6-monthly visits. If you have higher decay or gum risk, recent treatment, or are in active orthodontic care, we may agree a shorter cadence. We explain any recommendations so you know why timing matters.

If you notice ulcers that do not settle, new lumps, persistent soreness, or changes to your mouth or throat, contact us promptly. We will arrange a calm assessment, share what we can see, and signpost to further investigation if needed.
Do I need x-rays every time?
Not always. We follow clinical guidance and your risk profile to decide when x-rays are useful. We will explain the reason, dose, and what we are looking for before taking them.
Will you tell me if you see anything concerning?
Yes. We talk you through any changes, explain what is normal, and outline next steps if we spot something that needs a closer look.
How often should I book a check-up?
The right timing depends on your oral health and risk factors. Many people attend every six months, but some need more frequent visits and others less.
Can I combine a check-up with hygiene?
Often yes. We can align appointments so you have your check-up and hygiene visit together when schedules allow.

Replace one missing tooth with precision

A dental implant can be one way to replace a single missing tooth without relying on neighbouring teeth, unlike a traditional bridge. Planning starts with the end in mind: we assess the bite, gum shape, bone volume, and the position of adjacent teeth, then use CBCT and digital scans to plan implant placement to support a natural-looking crown. We’ll explain timing options, including immediate placement in selected cases, and discuss factors that affect predictability such as smoking, gum health, and tooth grinding. If an implant isn’t appropriate, we’ll outline alternatives such as a bridge or a removable option and help you choose a stable long-term solution.

Common questions about replacing several teeth
How many implants do I need for multiple missing teeth?

Several missing teeth can often be replaced using a smaller number of implants that support an implant-supported bridge or denture.

The exact approach depends on the number of teeth missing, their position, and how forces are distributed when you bite.
What is the timeline for multi-tooth implants?
We share a clear schedule from planning and placement through healing to the final bridge, with provisional options if needed to keep you chewing.
Will I be without teeth during healing?
We can often provide a temporary bridge or partial denture so you can smile and eat softer foods while the implants integrate.
Is it better than a traditional bridge?
Implant-supported bridges avoid drilling healthy neighbouring teeth and give more stability for chewing, while helping maintain bone.
How do I clean around an implant-supported bridge?
We demonstrate brushing and floss aids or interdental brushes to clean under the bridge and around the implant posts.
Does it hurt to place multiple implants?
Placement uses local anaesthetic with gentle techniques; expect pressure and some soreness afterwards, managed with our aftercare plan.

Replacing several teeth is a significant decision.

Clear explanation and staged planning help ensure the approach chosen fits your health, comfort, and long-term needs.

Full arch implant rehabilitation in Shoreham-by-Sea

Full-arch implant treatment is designed for people with failing teeth or missing teeth who want a stable fixed option across an entire jaw. It is not one single procedure — it’s a staged plan that may involve extractions, managing infection or gum disease, careful bite planning, and deciding whether immediate fixed teeth are appropriate. We use CBCT scans and digital planning to map bone and anatomy, then design implant positions to support a predictable final bridge. We’ll explain timelines, temporary options, maintenance requirements, and what factors affect suitability such as smoking, diabetes control, tooth grinding and bone volume. If full-arch implants aren’t right for you, we’ll outline other stable alternatives.
Consult-led planning to confirm if same-day or staged delivery is safest

What is a full-arch implant bridge?
Fixed teeth supported by carefully placed implants

A full-arch solution secures a custom bridge to a small number of implants (often four to six), giving a fixed alternative to loose dentures. It restores bite stability, supports clearer speech, and feels more comfortable when cleaned and maintained correctly over the long term.

Implant-retained dentures are dentures that are stabilised using dental implants placed in the jaw.

They are designed for people who find conventional dentures unstable or uncomfortable, but who are not suitable for — or do not want — fully fixed implant teeth. This approach sits between standard removable dentures and fixed implant solutions.

Understanding what implant-retained dentures can and cannot do helps you decide whether they are an appropriate step for your needs.

Implant-retained dentures use a small number of dental implants to help anchor a removable denture more securely.

The denture clips or attaches onto the implants, improving stability compared with a traditional denture that rests on the gums alone. The denture is still removable for cleaning and maintenance.

This combination of implants and a removable denture aims to improve comfort and function without the complexity of a fully fixed solution.

Compared with conventional dentures, implant-retained dentures are usually more stable, particularly during eating and speaking.

Because some of the support comes from implants, there is often less reliance on suction or muscle control alone. However, they remain removable appliances and do not feel the same as natural teeth or fixed implant restorations.

This difference is important to understand when considering expectations and long-term comfort.

Implant-retained dentures may be suitable for people who struggle with loose dentures and have sufficient bone to support implants.

They may not be appropriate where medical conditions, smoking, bone levels, or oral health make implant placement unsuitable. Cost and ongoing maintenance are also important considerations.

We assess suitability carefully and will discuss alternatives if another approach is likely to be more appropriate.

Treatment involves placing dental implants, allowing time for healing, and then fitting a denture designed to attach securely to those implants.

This is a staged process that takes place over several months rather than a single appointment. During this time, temporary solutions may be used.

We explain each stage clearly so you understand the timescales, commitments, and likely outcomes before treatment begins.

Bone grafting for dental implants in Shoreham-by-Sea

Bone grafting can be used when there isn’t enough bone volume to place an implant in a stable, predictable position. The need for grafting depends on the site, how long the tooth has been missing, gum thickness, and the shape of the bone. We plan using CBCT imaging and digital scans to assess anatomy and map where the final tooth needs to sit, then discuss options such as minor grafting at implant placement or a staged approach where grafting is done first. We’ll explain healing times, how grafting affects treatment length, and what alternatives may be suitable if grafting isn’t ideal for your circumstances.

Questions about grafting and sinus lifts
Do I often need bone grafting for implants?
No. We only recommend grafting when scans show there isn't enough bone to support an implant predictably.
A sinus lift gently raises the sinus floor and places graft material to create enough height for an implant near upper back teeth.
How long does grafting take to heal?
Healing times vary, but many grafts need several months before implant placement. We confirm your timeline after reviewing scans.
Can I have a temporary tooth while healing?
In many cases we can provide a provisional solution to maintain your smile while the graft heals.
Treatment is carried out with local anaesthetic and careful techniques; some soreness afterwards is normal and we support you with guidance.
Factors like smoking, diabetes control, and oral hygiene can influence healing. We tailor advice to your situation and monitor progress.
Costs depend on the type of grafting and number of implants. After assessment we share a clear plan with fees for each stage.

A sinus lift is a grafting procedure used in the upper back jaw when the sinus space and bone height limit implant placement. Planning is essential: we use CBCT imaging to measure bone height, assess sinus anatomy, and determine whether a small “internal” lift at the time of implant placement is feasible or whether a staged approach is safer. We’ll talk through expected healing times, how this affects the overall timeline, and what you can expect during recovery. Not every case requires a sinus lift, and not every patient is high standards served by one — we’ll explain alternatives such as shorter implants, different implant positions, or other tooth replacement options where appropriate.

Porcelain veneers vs digitally designed / 3D printed veneers
Printed vs ceramic veneers — what’s different?

Ceramic (porcelain) veneers and digitally printed veneer restorations are made from different materials and produced in different ways. Ceramic veneers are a long-established option. Printed restorations use modern scanning and printing technology to create precise, ultra-thin restorations for carefully selected cases. The right choice depends on your bite, goals, and long-term plan — not one material ‘winning’ for everyone.
Ceramic veneers (porcelain) — A long-established, lab-made option with excellent aesthetics and colour stability. Often chosen where a definitive ceramic solution is appropriate.

Digitally printed veneer restorations — A modern digital restorative option produced from scans and 3D printing workflows. Can be highly conservative in suitable cases and is planned around individual bite and function.

We offer advanced digitally designed veneer restorations using high-precision scanning and 3D printing technology. These restorations are custom designed from digital scans and printed from biocompatible dental resins used internationally in advanced restorative dentistry. The aim is a precise fit, controlled thickness, and a conservative approach — always guided by clinical judgement and careful case selection.
Precision fit from digital scans — We design from detailed 3D scans so the restoration is planned in relation to your tooth shape, contact points, and bite.
Ultra-thin, conservative designs (when suitable) — In the right cases, we can minimise tooth preparation and still achieve a meaningful aesthetic change.
Digitally repeatable workflow — Digital planning improves consistency and makes it easier to refine the design across appointments if needed.
Hand-finished by your clinician — Printed restorations are shaped, finished, and polished carefully by hand for a natural, bespoke result.
Case selection + bite planning first — We assess bite forces, tooth position, enamel, and habits (like grinding) before recommending printed veneer restorations.
Staged treatment planning options — Depending on your situation, these restorations may be used as long-term or medium-term aesthetic solutions, or as part of a staged plan.
We outline when printed veneers are appropriate and when a ceramic route may be recommended.

We use biocompatible dental resins supplied for regulated dental applications and process them strictly according to manufacturer instructions. The final restoration is then finished and polished by hand to refine shape, texture, and shine. If ceramic is the better option for your goals or bite, we’ll tell you clearly.
Biocompatible dental resins — Chosen for clinical suitability and processed under manufacturer guidelines.
Hand-finished and polished — Designed digitally, then refined by hand for a natural result.
Honest guidance on alternatives — Where ceramic or another restoration is more appropriate, we’ll recommend it.

Composite bonding for measured smile refinement

Composite bonding, sometimes called dental bonding, uses tooth-coloured resin in layers to rebuild edges and refine shape with minimal drilling. We aim to preserve enamel wherever possible, plan conservatively, and explain how wear and staining are managed over time.
Tooth-preserving contouring with light surface preparation
Resins layered to match shade, translucency, and texture
Calm appointment pacing with time for review before final polishing

Composite bonding is a conservative cosmetic treatment that improves the appearance of teeth by adding tooth-coloured resin in controlled layers.

It is commonly used to refine shape, close small gaps, or repair minor chips. Because it usually involves little or no removal of natural tooth structure, it is a lower-intervention option than treatments that require more preparation.

Suitability depends on the condition of your teeth, your bite, and what you want to achieve. We assess these carefully before recommending treatment.
What composite bonding can and can’t do
Composite bonding uses a resin material that is shaped directly onto the tooth and then hardened using a curing light.

The material is colour-matched to your natural teeth and blended carefully so the result looks subtle rather than artificial. The process relies on careful shaping and finishing rather than laboratory fabrication.
Bonding is typically completed in a single visit for each area treated.

We begin with 3D scans and clinical photographs, then design the proposed changes digitally. We share mock-ups so you can preview the direction. Guided placement and finishing maps help keep the resin precise and consistent, and support injection moulding when it offers the safest level of control.

Injection moulded composite uses a digital design and silicone or printed guides to place resin accurately. This helps keep edge lengths, embrasures, and tooth widths consistent, improves symmetry across multiple teeth, and reduces variation during placement.
Digital scans and wax-ups map planned tooth shapes before treatment
Silicone keys or printed guides control resin volume for repeatable placement
Predictable edge lengths and contact points with fewer mid-appointment adjustments
Efficient when treating several teeth together or refining symmetry after orthodontics
How composite bonding fits with other options
When colour is the main concern, dentist-led whitening is usually recommended before bonding so shades align
If teeth are rotated or crowded, aligners or other orthodontic treatment can set the foundation before cosmetic bonding
For larger shape changes or durability, porcelain veneers or digitally designed 3D veneers may be more appropriate
Composite bonding often forms part of an Align → Bleach → Composite pathway, with veneers reserved for specific needs
Composite bonding is not permanent. Over time, the material can wear, stain, or chip, particularly at the edges.
Longevity varies between individuals and depends on factors such as bite forces, habits, and oral hygiene. Maintenance or repair may be required in the future.
We discuss realistic expectations and ongoing care before treatment begins.
When bonding isn’t the best choice
Composite bonding is best suited to patients with healthy teeth and gums who want small to moderate cosmetic changes.

It may not be suitable where there is heavy tooth wear, active grinding, or where larger structural changes are required. In these cases, alternative treatments may provide more predictable long-term results.
We will discuss suitability openly so you can make an informed decision.

How long does composite bonding last?
Composite bonding can last for several years, but it is not permanent. Over time the material can wear, stain, or chip, and maintenance may be needed.
Yes. Chips or edge wear can usually be repaired by smoothing and adding new resin, without removing the rest of the bonding.

A dental bridge replaces one or more missing teeth by supporting a fixed tooth (or teeth) between neighbouring teeth or implants. Suitability depends on the health of the supporting teeth, gum condition, bite forces and the size and position of the gap. We assess the area carefully, because a bridge should feel stable, cleanable and comfortable in the long term. In some cases, an implant or a removable option may be more appropriate, particularly if the neighbouring teeth are intact. If a bridge is a good fit, we’ll explain material options, preparation, expected maintenance, and how to keep the margins healthy with daily cleaning.

When a dental bridge may be suitable
When a dental bridge may be suitable
A bridge may be considered when a tooth is missing and the neighbouring teeth can support a replacement.
In some cases, a bridge is chosen for practical reasons, including speed, suitability, or preference for a fixed option.
However, bridges are not right for everyone. The condition of the supporting teeth and gums matters, as does the bite and the long-term outlook.
We’ll explain why a bridge is being recommended — and what alternatives exist.

A dental bridge is a way of replacing one or more missing teeth by attaching a false tooth to neighbouring teeth.

A bridge can restore appearance and function, but it needs careful planning so it’s comfortable and predictable over the long term.

We’ll assess your teeth, gums, and bite and explain whether a bridge is suitable or whether other options may be more appropriate.
There are different types of bridge, and the most appropriate option depends on the teeth involved and how they are being supported.
We’ll explain what type is being recommended, why it suits your situation, and what to expect in day-to-day life.

Intraoral scanning records the prepared teeth, opposing bite, and soft tissue profile. The data helps the lab design pontics with natural emergence profiles and retainers that seat smoothly, reducing chairside adjustments and protecting the gums.
Bridges need good daily cleaning and regular review to remain healthy and comfortable.
Cleaning around and under a bridge is different from cleaning natural teeth, and we’ll show you practical ways to do this.
Regular reviews help us monitor the supporting teeth and gums and address any issues early.

Bridges are made to match your other teeth in shape and shade, but the final appearance depends on the supporting teeth, gum contours, and the space being replaced. We’ll discuss what can be achieved for your situation.

Lifespan varies with bite forces, cleaning, and the health of the supporting teeth and gums. With good maintenance and regular reviews, many bridges last for years, but we’ll outline the factors that affect longevity.
Will it feel strange at first?
It can feel different at first as your tongue and bite adjust. Most people adapt over time, and we can make adjustments if anything feels high or uncomfortable.
Once you’re comfortable, most people return to normal eating. We may advise avoiding very hard foods or habits that put excess force on the bridge, especially early on.

Yes, implants can be an alternative when suitable, especially if the neighbouring teeth are healthy and you prefer not to prepare them. We’ll explain the pros, limits, timing, and costs so you can compare options.

A dental crown is used when a tooth needs more protection than a filling can provide.

Crowns are most often recommended for teeth that are heavily worn, cracked, weakened, or have already had extensive treatment. The aim is to protect what remains of the tooth and help it function comfortably for the long term.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, crowns are planned carefully, not routinely.

When a crown isn’t the best option

Crowns aren’t always the answer.

In some situations, alternatives such as fillings, onlays, or monitoring may be more appropriate. If we think a crown isn’t the best long-term solution, we’ll explain our reasoning clearly.
We explain when alternatives may be more appropriate
We outline the reasons so you can decide confidently
What to expect from crown treatment
Who is a suitable candidate for a crown?
Crowns are recommended when a tooth is cracked, heavily filled, or needs reinforcement after root canal treatment. If a more conservative option is viable, we will explain that first.
Are there alternatives to a crown?
Depending on remaining tooth structure, options may include an onlay, bonded repair, or monitoring. We map crack risk and bite forces to advise when full coverage is the safer route.
How long will my crown last?
Durability depends on bite forces, hygiene, and material. We choose ceramics or metal-ceramic options to suit your case and schedule reviews to check margins and contacts over time.
What maintenance does a crown need?
Clean carefully around the margins and attend regular hygiene appointments. Bite checks help us refine contacts and spot early signs of wear or gum inflammation.
What are the risks or limitations?
Crowns can chip, loosen, or develop decay at the margins if hygiene or bite balance is poor. We plan coverage height and consider splints if grinding is present to reduce these risks.
Fees vary by material, laboratory input, and any additional planning such as scan-guided design. We provide a written estimate and outline phased treatment if needed.
Will the crown match my other teeth?
We shade-map your neighbouring teeth and use digital scans to guide shape and translucency. The aim is a natural blend that suits your smile and gumline.

Teeth whitening lightens the natural colour of teeth using peroxide-based gels, most commonly with custom trays worn at home and, in selected cases, an in-practice approach. Whitening works best when teeth and gums are healthy, so we begin with an assessment to check for decay, leaking fillings, gum inflammation, and causes of sensitivity. We explain what shade change is realistic for your starting colour and how results can be maintained with appropriate top-ups. Whitening does not change the colour of crowns, veneers, or fillings, so we plan around existing dental work and discuss options if a more even overall result is needed.

Teeth whitening is intended to lighten the natural colour of your teeth. It does not alter tooth structure; instead, it works by breaking down stains that have developed over time.

Results vary between individuals. Your starting shade, the type of staining present, and your overall oral health all influence how much lightening is possible.

Before starting, it is important to understand what whitening can and cannot achieve. A proper assessment helps confirm suitability and keeps expectations realistic.

Professional whitening uses regulated gels that penetrate the tooth surface and break down stain molecules.

The tooth is lightened from within rather than by removing enamel. When used under dental supervision, whitening is a controlled and predictable treatment.

Over-the-counter products may appear similar, but under UK regulations they are limited in strength and effectiveness.
Whitening as part of ABC dentistry

Not everyone is suitable for teeth whitening.

Teeth and gums need to be healthy before treatment. Whitening does not change the colour of fillings, crowns, or veneers, which can affect the overall appearance if these are present on visible teeth.

We assess your oral health, existing dental work, and the cause of discolouration before recommending whitening. In some cases, alternative treatments may be more appropriate.

Sensitivity can happen during whitening, but it is usually temporary. We adjust wear times, use desensitising products, and pause treatment if needed to keep things comfortable.
Whitening results fade gradually over time and vary between people. We advise on habits that affect shade and discuss if or when a refresh might be appropriate.

Home whitening uses custom-made trays and professional whitening gel to gradually brighten your teeth in a controlled way. The benefit of the home approach is precision: the trays are tailored to your teeth, the gel is used in measured doses, and you can pace treatment to manage sensitivity. If you have existing restorations on the front teeth, we’ll explain how whitening affects the natural tooth but not the restorations, and how we can plan any replacements afterwards if needed for a balanced look.

Whitening top-ups are short booster phases used after an initial course to maintain brightness over time. The need for top-ups varies — it depends on your starting shade, diet, staining habits, and how long you’d like the result to stay at a particular level. We’ll explain sensible intervals and how to avoid overuse, because more gel isn’t necessarily better and can increase sensitivity. If you already have custom trays, we can advise on appropriate gels and protocols; if not, we’ll assess your teeth and gums first. We’ll also discuss how top-ups interact with existing crowns or composite edges to keep your smile looking even.

If your teeth are sensitive, whitening may still be possible — but it needs careful planning and the right pacing. Sensitivity can come from exposed dentine, gum recession, enamel wear, micro-cracks, or underlying decay, so we start by identifying the cause rather than simply “pushing through”. We’ll talk you through lower-dose gels, shorter wear times, staged progress, and desensitising strategies to keep you comfortable. In some cases, addressing wear, bite stress or gum inflammation first makes whitening more predictable. If whitening isn’t the right option at the moment, we’ll explain alternatives and how to move towards it safely.

Custom trays that limit gel contact with gums
Pacing and breaks built in to reduce flare-ups

Often yes, once we rule out decay or cracks. We may start slower, use desensitising support, and space applications further apart.
What should I do if I feel a zing?
Pause for a day or two and let us know. We can adjust frequency, recommend relief products, or review fit.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, orthodontic treatment is approached as part of a wider plan — not as a one-size-fits-all solution.

Why might orthodontic treatment be recommended?
Orthodontics may be considered when tooth position or bite contributes to crowding, spacing, bite imbalance, difficulty cleaning, or excessive wear.
Is orthodontic treatment only for teenagers?
No. Many adults choose orthodontics later in life to address long-standing concerns or to support function and stability.
What types of orthodontic treatment are available?
Options may include clear aligners, fixed appliances, or limited treatment focused on specific areas. Suitability depends on individual circumstances.
How long does orthodontic treatment take?

Will I need retainers after treatment?
Yes. Retainers help maintain the result and reduce the risk of teeth drifting over time.

A full smile makeover is a way of looking at your teeth together, rather than treating individual problems in isolation. People often come to us with a mix of concerns — how their teeth look, how they function, or how they’ve changed over time.

Rather than jumping straight to treatment, we start by understanding what matters to you and what’s realistically achievable. In many cases, there is more than one way forward. Some options are simpler and more conservative, while others are more involved and take longer.

Our role is to help you understand those options clearly, including their limits, so you can decide what feels right for you.

---
Plan designed from scans and photos

Planning is the most important part of any smile makeover. This usually involves careful examination, photographs, scans, and discussion, rather than making quick decisions.

This stage helps us see how your teeth fit together, where changes may be helpful, and where they may not be appropriate. It also allows time to talk through expectations and agree a plan that makes sense before any treatment starts.

---
Tools that keep complex plans clear

A full smile makeover is usually built up in stages. Each stage has a purpose, and not every stage is needed for every person. The aim is to move forward in a controlled way, rather than trying to do everything at once.

Some stages focus on creating space or alignment, others on improving appearance or repairing wear. We plan these steps carefully so that earlier treatment supports what comes later.

---
We start by understanding your concerns, examining your teeth and bite, and discussing what you’d like to change. This helps identify which problems need addressing first and which can be left alone.
Where needed, early treatment may focus on alignment, bite position, or stabilising the teeth. These steps often make later cosmetic or restorative work more predictable.
Final stages may involve improving shape, colour, or repairing damage. The exact treatments depend on the plan agreed earlier and are tailored to your individual situation.
If you’re considering a full smile makeover, the first step is a conversation. An assessment allows us to look at your teeth properly and talk through whether this approach makes sense for you.
Who is a full smile makeover for?

It may be suitable for people with several concerns they’d like to address together, such as worn, discoloured, misaligned or damaged teeth. An assessment is needed to see whether this approach is appropriate.
Depending on your needs, this could include orthodontic treatment, whitening, bonding, veneers, crowns or other restorative work. Not every treatment is needed for every person.
Timeframes vary. Some treatment plans take a few months, while others are staged over a longer period. We’ll talk this through during planning so you know what to expect.
Yes. In many cases, more limited treatment can still improve appearance or function. We’ll discuss alternatives and the likely trade-offs.
Longevity depends on the treatments used, how your teeth are looked after, and factors such as grinding or diet. Ongoing care and maintenance are important.
A consultation is an opportunity to ask questions, understand your options, and decide what feels right for you, without any obligation to proceed.

3D and digital dentistry refers to the way we plan, design, and carry out dental treatment using detailed digital scans rather than relying only on traditional impressions and estimates.

For patients, this means we can see your teeth, bite, and jaw in far greater detail before treatment starts. Digital scans allow us to plan carefully, explain options clearly, and reduce guesswork at every stage.

This technology supports safer planning, clearer communication, and more predictable outcomes. It does not replace clinical judgement or experience — it supports it.
Intraoral scan and photography for reference
Digital design preview with space to adjust shape and bite
In-house 3D print or mill with controlled materials

Patients who want predictable, visual planning
From a patient point of view, digital dentistry is mainly about clarity and confidence.

You are able to see proposed treatment plans, understand why a particular approach is recommended, and ask informed questions before decisions are made. Planning happens in advance, which often reduces adjustments, remakes, or surprises later on.
For many treatments, digital workflows also allow for fewer appointments and more accurate fitting restorations, although this depends on the type of care involved.
Clear checkpoints from scan to maintenance
We use 3D and digital planning across a wide range of treatments, including crowns and bridges, dental implants, orthodontic aligners, and more complex restorative work.
Not every treatment requires digital planning, and it is not used automatically. We recommend it when it adds clarity, accuracy, or safety to your care.
Your dentist will explain whether digital planning is appropriate for your situation and why.
Timelines vary by case complexity; we share ranges and review points upfront.

Instead of taking physical moulds, we use digital scanners and imaging to build a precise three-dimensional picture of your teeth and mouth.

These scans are used to plan treatments such as crowns, implants, aligners, or complex restorations. Because the information is visual, we can show you what we see and talk through options in a way that is easier to understand.

Digital planning helps us check spacing, bite relationships, and fit before treatment begins, rather than discovering issues part-way through.
Digital imaging allows us to assess structures that are difficult to judge by eye alone, such as tooth position below the gum or bone levels around teeth.
When X-ray-based scans are used, they are prescribed carefully and only when clinically justified. We follow UK radiation guidelines and always balance benefit against exposure.
Digital tools support careful planning, but they do not replace clinical checks, consent discussions, or hands-on assessment.
When do you recommend porcelain instead of printing?
We recommend porcelain for cases needing maximum longevity, high gloss, or colour stability. Printed options are useful for provisional stages or conservative veneers when appropriate.
How fast can printed dentures or guards be ready?
Digital scanning and in-house production shorten turnaround times; we share a range after your assessment and schedule fit appointments accordingly.
Do printed implant restorations need different maintenance?
We pair them with occlusion checks, hygiene plans, and torque reviews. You’ll know the follow-up cadence before treatment begins.
Can designs be adjusted after I see the preview?
Yes. We review shape, bite, and shade options with you, then adjust the plan before production.
Digital files let us reproduce or adjust quickly if needed, with clinician review to avoid repeating issues.

A dental emergency is any situation where pain, swelling, trauma, or infection needs prompt assessment.

Not all urgent dental problems look the same, and not all require the same response. Our role is to assess the situation, relieve pain where possible, and decide what treatment is needed to stabilise the problem safely.

If you are unsure whether your situation counts as an emergency, contacting the practice for advice is appropriate.
Common reasons people contact us urgently
Dental emergencies may include severe toothache, facial swelling, dental trauma, bleeding that does not settle, or signs of infection.
Some problems feel urgent but may not require immediate treatment, while others benefit from early assessment even if pain is mild. Speaking to a dentist allows us to prioritise care appropriately.
If you are experiencing dental pain or swelling, contact the practice as soon as you can during opening hours so we can advise on the next steps.
We will ask about your symptoms and may offer advice, an urgent appointment, or referral depending on the situation. Outside normal hours, guidance will be provided on how to access appropriate care.
If swelling affects breathing, swallowing, or causes rapidly worsening symptoms, urgent medical attention may be required.
What you can expect at an emergency visit

Emergency dental care focuses on assessment, pain control, and stabilisation.

The aim is to address the immediate problem safely, then discuss longer-term treatment once the urgent issue has settled. In some cases, definitive treatment is not appropriate during an emergency visit.

We will explain findings clearly and outline any recommended follow-up care.

Following emergency care, further treatment may be recommended to address the underlying cause.

We’ll explain any findings clearly and discuss whether monitoring, further investigation, or planned treatment is appropriate.

You’ll have time to consider options once the immediate situation has settled.
Contact the practice so we can advise on urgency and next steps.
When urgent care may not be necessary
When urgent care may not be necessary

Some issues can wait a short time — for example, a small chip with no pain, a lost filling that isn’t sensitive, or mild sensitivity that settles quickly.

If you’re unsure, it’s still worth contacting us. We can help you work out whether it sounds urgent, and what to do while you’re waiting.

If you’re in pain, have swelling, or you’ve damaged a tooth, an emergency appointment is about stabilising the situation.

That usually means diagnosis, getting you comfortable, reducing risk, and agreeing the next sensible step. Sometimes we can fix the problem on the day. Sometimes the safest care is staged.

We’ll explain what we can see, what’s realistic, and what you can do next — without pressure.
Work out what’s happening and how urgent it is

Dental problems rarely happen at a convenient time.

If you’re not sure whether you need to be seen urgently, contact us. We’ll ask a few focused questions and advise timing.

If you have rapid facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then let us know as soon as you can.

Swelling of the gum, face, or jaw
A broken, cracked, or sharply chipped tooth
