If swelling, fever, or swallowing/breathing issues develop, seek urgent medical help

Emergency care works best when we diagnose the cause properly, not just the symptom.

Pain can come from decay, infection, cracks, gum problems, or failed restorations — and the right solution depends on what we find.

Seeing you early often gives more conservative options, better comfort, and fewer repeat flare-ups.
What an emergency appointment can involve

An emergency visit usually includes an examination and, where appropriate, X-rays to understand what’s happening under the surface.

We’ll explain the likely cause, discuss options and costs, and agree the safest next step. That might be a temporary stabilisation, a simple repair, or a plan for staged treatment.

Our aim is clarity, comfort, and a sensible route forward.
Review the likely steps and plan what happens next.
Can you always fix the problem on the day?

Not always — it depends on the cause and what’s safest for the tooth. Sometimes we can provide a definitive repair. Other times the priority is stabilisation and pain control, followed by a planned appointment for the longer-term fix. We’ll explain this clearly at the visit.
What if I am nervous about urgent treatment?

Tell us. We’ll take a calm, step-by-step approach: clear explanation, breaks if you need them, and a plan that feels manageable. Emergency dentistry isn’t about rushing you — it’s about getting you safe and comfortable.
Do I need a referral for an emergency visit?

No. You can contact the practice directly. If we think you need another service urgently (for example, medical assessment after trauma or signs of a serious spreading infection), we’ll tell you clearly and help you choose the safest next step.
Tell us what has happened so we can reserve time and guide you before you travel.

Severe toothache can feel urgent, and it’s hard to think about anything else. Here in Shoreham-by-Sea, we see how quickly pain can disrupt sleep, eating, and work.

Pain relief can help you cope, but it doesn’t fix the underlying cause. Toothache can come from decay, infection, cracks, gum problems, grinding, or a filling or crown that’s failed.

We’ll assess what’s going on, explain what we can see, and recommend the most sensible way to settle pain and protect the tooth.

Toothache can range from mild twinges to severe, throbbing pain that disrupts sleep. If it’s persistent, worsening, or triggered by biting, heat, or cold, it’s worth getting checked even if it comes and goes.

We can talk through what’s happening and advise timing. If pain is getting worse, you notice swelling, fever, a bad taste, or you cannot open your mouth comfortably, call us promptly.

If you have rapid facial swelling, fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then let us know as soon as you can.

Pain often means the tooth or surrounding tissues are under stress.

Painkillers and temporary measures can take the edge off, but they cannot resolve infection, nerve damage, or structural problems such as cracks or failed restorations. The safest route is a proper assessment so the right treatment is chosen for you.

Our aim is to diagnose the cause accurately, settle pain, and help you avoid repeat flare-ups.

At an emergency appointment we start with an assessment, look for the cause, and confirm a diagnosis with any checks or X-rays needed.

Where appropriate we provide immediate stabilisation to relieve pain and protect the tooth. Not all treatment is completed in one visit, so we’ll outline the next stages and timing.

Options may include replacing or repairing a filling, root canal treatment to treat infection inside the tooth, gum treatment, adjusting the bite, or in some cases removing a tooth that can’t be predictably saved.

We’ll explain the findings and the pros and cons of each option before anything is done.
Understand the likely steps and plan the next visit.
Can I wait to see if the pain settles?

Sometimes pain eases for a while, but the cause may still be there. If pain is severe, waking you, lingering, or getting worse, it’s best to get advice promptly. Contact us and we’ll guide you on timing.

Our aim is to get you comfortable first. We use effective local anaesthetic and we work in a calm, step-by-step way. If you’re anxious, tell us — pacing, breaks, and clear explanation make a big difference.
What if the pain starts overnight?

Use normal pain relief if safe for you (follow the packet guidance), keep the area clean, and avoid chewing on that side. If you develop swelling, fever, or difficulty swallowing/breathing, seek urgent medical help. Contact us as soon as we’re open and we’ll advise next steps.
We will guide you on immediate steps and bring you in quickly to relieve pain.

A dental abscess is an infection that can build pressure and cause significant pain, swelling, or a bad taste.

Sometimes symptoms come and go, but the underlying infection usually needs proper assessment and treatment. Leaving it can allow the infection to spread and can make the tooth harder to save.

If you have facial swelling, difficulty swallowing, fever, or you feel generally unwell, seek urgent advice and contact us as soon as possible.
Assess the cause and how urgent it is
Plan the most sensible long-term fix

Infections can start quietly — sometimes as a dull ache, sometimes as sensitivity, and sometimes with no pain until swelling appears.

An abscess can come from the tooth nerve, from gum disease, or from a crack or deep decay letting bacteria in.

If you’re unsure whether it’s an emergency, call us. We can advise on urgency and what to do while you’re waiting to be seen.
Throbbing toothache or pain that wakes you
Swelling of the gum, face, or jaw
A bad taste, pus, or a spot on the gum that drains
Pain on biting or a tooth that feels raised
Fever, feeling unwell, or swollen glands (seek urgent advice)
Contact us promptly so we can advise urgency and book the right appointment

Warm salt-water rinses can help comfort (do not apply heat to facial swelling)
Avoid chewing on that side and stick to softer foods

Infections are not always solved by antibiotics alone. Antibiotics can be appropriate in some situations, but the source of infection usually still needs treating.

That might mean draining the infection, cleaning and sealing the tooth with root canal treatment, treating gum infection, or removing a tooth that cannot be saved.

Our job is to assess the cause, explain the realistic options, and help you stabilise quickly — then plan longer-term care in a calm, sensible way.

Treatment depends on where the infection is coming from and how advanced it is.

Options may include local measures to relieve pressure, root canal treatment to try to save a tooth, periodontal (gum) treatment, or extraction when the tooth cannot be predictably restored.

If antibiotics are needed, we’ll explain why, what they can and can’t do, and what follow-up is required.
Review treatment options and plan the next steps.

Sometimes antibiotics are necessary, especially if there is spreading swelling or you are unwell. But an abscess usually needs the source treated as well — for example drainage, root canal treatment, gum treatment, or extraction. We’ll advise what’s appropriate after assessment.
Will the swelling go away on its own?

Symptoms can ease if an abscess drains, but the infection often remains and can flare again. Leaving it can increase risk of spread and reduce the chance of saving the tooth. It’s safest to get it assessed.
Can I work or travel after treatment?

Facial swelling can be serious. Contact us urgently. If you have fever, difficulty swallowing, or breathing problems, seek urgent medical help immediately (A&E / 999) and then update us as soon as you can.

If you’ve chipped a tooth, cracked a corner, or something feels sharp or painful, it’s worth getting it checked promptly.

Some problems look small but involve deeper cracks or exposed dentine, which can lead to sensitivity, infection, or a larger fracture.

We’ll assess what’s happened, explain what we can see, and recommend the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable.
Quick smoothing to prevent cuts to cheeks or tongue

Teeth can chip or crack for lots of reasons — biting something hard, an old filling giving way, grinding, or an accident.

Sometimes it’s mainly cosmetic. Sometimes it’s an early warning that the tooth is under stress.

If you’re unsure, we’d rather you call and ask. We can advise whether it sounds urgent and what to do in the meantime.
A sharp edge that catches your tongue or floss
Pain on biting or when you release the bite

If a sharp edge is cutting you, cover it temporarily with sugar-free gum or dental wax
Use your normal pain relief if needed and safe for you (follow the packet guidance)

A chip or crack isn’t always an emergency, but it can change quickly.

Small fractures can spread, and exposed dentine can become very sensitive. In some cases, cracks allow bacteria to reach the nerve, leading to infection.

Seeing you early gives us more conservative options — and helps prevent the problem turning into a bigger repair.

Treatment depends on where the crack is, how deep it goes, and how much tooth is missing.

Options may include smoothing a sharp edge, a bonded repair (composite), replacing or reshaping an old filling, or protecting the tooth with an onlay or crown.

If the nerve is involved, root canal treatment may be needed — but we only recommend that when it’s clearly indicated.
Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.
Sometimes a small chip can wait a short time, but it’s best to get advice. Chips can expose dentine, increase sensitivity, or develop into a larger fracture. Call us and we’ll guide you on timing.
Will I need a crown straight away?

Not always. We usually start with the least invasive repair that keeps the tooth stable. That may be smoothing, a bonded repair, or replacing a filling. A crown or onlay is recommended when the tooth needs extra protection.
Is it safe to keep eating?

Try to avoid chewing on the affected side until we’ve assessed the tooth. Softer foods and careful cleaning help. If biting triggers sharp pain, stop and contact us as that can suggest a deeper crack.

A knocked-out adult tooth can sometimes be saved, but timing and how the tooth is handled matter.

If you can get advice immediately, bring the tooth with you and avoid touching the root. If it’s safe to do so, simple first aid can improve the chances of a good outcome — but after an accident it isn’t always possible to do everything perfectly.

Call us straight away so we can guide you on the next steps and how urgently you need to be seen.
Handle the tooth carefully (avoid the root)
Get assessed promptly for the best chance of stabilisation

Having a tooth knocked out is frightening, and it often happens alongside a fall, collision, or sports injury.

If the tooth is an adult tooth, replantation may be possible depending on timing and what has happened to the tooth and socket.

If you’re unsure whether it’s a baby tooth or an adult tooth, or there are other injuries, call us and we’ll guide you to the safest next step.
A tooth completely out of the mouth
Bleeding from the socket or gum
Pain, swelling, or a cut lip/cheek alongside the injury
A tooth that feels loose or displaced after impact
Check for head injury, heavy bleeding, or breathing problems and seek urgent medical help if needed
Find the tooth, pick it up by the crown (not the root), and avoid scrubbing it
If it’s dirty, rinse gently for a few seconds with milk or saline (avoid disinfectants)
Keep it moist: ideally in milk, saline, or inside the cheek if safe (not in water)
Call us immediately so we can advise urgency and prepare for assessment

The tissues that help an adult tooth reattach can be damaged quickly if the tooth dries out or is handled roughly.

Even with prompt care, replantation isn’t always possible or successful. Early assessment gives the best chance of stabilising the situation and planning the next steps.

We’ll also check for associated injuries, fractures, and whether nearby teeth have been damaged or loosened.

Treatment depends on whether the tooth is an adult tooth, how long it has been out, how it has been stored, and the condition of the socket and surrounding bone.

Options may include careful replantation and stabilisation (splinting) where appropriate, monitoring healing, and follow-up assessment. In some situations, we discuss replacement options if replantation isn’t possible.

We’ll explain the likely risks, the aftercare required, and what long-term maintenance might involve.
Understand the immediate steps and plan what happens next.
Can a baby tooth be replanted?

Usually no. Baby (primary) teeth are not normally replanted because it can damage the developing adult tooth underneath. If you’re unsure whether it’s a baby or adult tooth, call us and we’ll advise quickly.
What if the tooth looks damaged?

If the tooth is broken, cracked, or visibly contaminated, replantation may be less suitable — but it depends on the situation. Keep the tooth safe and moist, avoid touching the root, and contact us so we can assess what’s realistic.
Do I need a tetanus check?

If the injury involved a dirty wound, soil, or a cut that may have been contaminated, a tetanus check may be sensible. If you’re unsure, contact your GP, NHS 111, or urgent care for advice — and still contact us so we can deal with the dental side promptly.

If a crown, veneer or filling has come out, it can feel urgent — especially if the tooth is sensitive or looks unfinished.

In many cases the tooth can be protected and repaired conservatively, but timing matters. A lost restoration can leave sharp edges, exposed dentine, or a tooth that is more likely to fracture.

We’ll assess what’s happened, explain the options clearly, and help you stabilise the tooth as simply as possible.
Protect the tooth and reduce sensitivity

Decide whether it can be re-cemented or needs replacing

Restorations can come loose for lots of reasons — wear over time, biting something hard, decay underneath, or the tooth changing shape.

Sometimes it’s a straightforward re-cement. Sometimes it’s a sign the tooth needs a different kind of protection.

If you still have the crown or veneer, keep it safe and bring it with you. We can often learn a lot from seeing it.

If the tooth is sharp, cover it temporarily with sugar-free gum or dental wax
Keep the crown/veneer if you have it and bring it with you (don’t force it back on)

Why it’s worth seeing us promptly

When a restoration comes out, the underlying tooth is often more vulnerable than it looks.

Exposed dentine can be very sensitive, and the tooth can fracture more easily — especially if it’s already heavily filled. If there is decay or a crack underneath, delaying can reduce the options.

Seeing you early helps us protect the tooth, manage discomfort, and plan a repair that lasts.

The right solution depends on why the restoration came out and what the tooth looks like underneath.

Options may include re-cementing the existing crown or veneer (if it’s intact and the fit is still appropriate), replacing a filling, or making a new restoration if the tooth needs better protection.

If decay or a crack is present, we’ll explain the findings and the most sensible way to stabilise the tooth long-term.
Compare connected steps and plan the next visit.
Can I eat before the appointment?

Sometimes, yes. If the crown is intact and the tooth underneath is healthy and stable, re-cementing can be a good option. If decay, a crack, or fit issues are present, replacing the crown may be safer long-term.
Will you reuse my crown or veneer?

In most cases, swallowed dental restorations pass through without causing harm. If you have breathing symptoms, chest pain, or you think it may have been inhaled, seek urgent medical advice. Either way, contact us so we can protect the tooth and plan the next step.
Is it urgent if I have no pain?

Temporary dental cements can sometimes help short-term, but they can also trap bacteria if used incorrectly. The safest approach is to keep the area clean, avoid chewing on that side, and call us. If you do use a temporary product, treat it as a short stop-gap, not a fix.

Dental trauma can range from chipped enamel to displaced or loosened teeth, fractures, and injuries to gums or supporting bone. What matters most is prompt assessment: we check tooth stability, nerve response, bite changes and soft tissue injury, and take X-rays to rule out hidden fractures. Treatment might include smoothing or repairing a chip, splinting a tooth, dressing an exposed nerve, or planning follow-up care if the tooth’s nerve is at risk. We’ll also advise on pain control and what to avoid while the area heals. If a tooth has been knocked out, time is critical — see that page for immediate steps.
If bleeding, apply gentle pressure with a clean cloth or gauze
Rinse with cool water to clear debris
Save any tooth fragments or restorations
Use a cold compress on the outside of the cheek to reduce swelling
Contact us promptly; seek urgent medical help if you suspect other injuries
Early evaluation lets us stabilise teeth, check for hidden fractures, and plan repairs before complications develop. It also helps us coordinate with medical teams if needed.
Treatment may include smoothing edges, splinting loose teeth, placing temporary coverings, prescribing medication, or coordinating imaging and follow-up restorative care.

Do I need X-rays after an accident?
We will advise after examining the area. Imaging helps check for fractures or root damage that are not visible.
What if a tooth feels loose?
Keep it clean, avoid wiggling it, and contact us. We may splint it to nearby teeth while it heals.
Can you help with mouth cuts?
Yes. We assess soft tissue injuries, clean the area, and advise if medical attention or stitches are needed.

Three-dimensional scanning allows us to see dental structures in more detail than traditional two-dimensional X-rays.

CBCT (cone beam computed tomography) provides a 3D view of teeth, bone, nerves, and surrounding anatomy. It’s used selectively, when additional information genuinely helps with diagnosis or planning.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, CBCT scanning is used to support careful decision-making — not as a routine step for every patient.

What 3D scanning shows that standard X-rays don’t

Unlike traditional X-rays, CBCT scans show structures in three dimensions.

This can help us assess bone thickness and shape, the position of nerves and sinuses, the extent of infection or fractures, and how teeth relate to surrounding structures.

Having this information upfront helps reduce uncertainty and improve planning accuracy.

Why might a CBCT scan be recommended?
CBCT scanning is advised when standard X-rays don’t provide enough information, such as implant planning, complex extractions, impacted teeth, or ongoing symptoms after root treatment.
Do I need a CBCT scan for every problem?
Not every dental problem requires 3D imaging. If standard X-rays and clinical examination provide sufficient information, a CBCT scan won’t be recommended.
Results support diagnosis and planning, helping confirm whether treatment is appropriate, refine the proposed approach, or highlight when an alternative plan is safer.
Can I ask about radiation and safety?
Yes. We follow UK guidance on justification and exposure, use settings that minimise dose, and are happy to discuss radiation levels before proceeding.
You’ll stand or sit still while the scanner rotates briefly around your head. The scan takes seconds and is non-invasive, with no contact or discomfort.

If you’re unsure why a CBCT scan has been suggested, or whether it’s necessary, we encourage you to ask.

What to know before you proceed
Who is suitable for an inlay or onlay?
They are best for teeth with larger cavities or failing fillings where enough healthy structure remains. We will advise if a crown, repair, or monitoring is safer.
What are the alternatives if I am not suitable?
Depending on the tooth, options may include a bonded filling, a crown for full coverage, or smoothing and monitoring. We explain why each choice would or would not work for your bite.
How long do inlays and onlays last?
Longevity varies with bite forces, material, and cleaning. We choose ceramics or composites suited to your tooth and review the fit at check-ups to catch wear early.
How do I look after the restoration?
Daily cleaning around the margins and attending reviews keeps the tooth and gums healthy. Avoid very hard foods on the tooth while it settles, and let us adjust the bite if it feels high.
What are the risks or limitations?
Restorations can debond or chip if forces are heavy or hygiene is poor. We assess crack lines and grinding habits beforehand and may recommend a protective splint if needed.
How are inlays and onlays priced?
Fees reflect material choice, lab fabrication, and the planning needed for your case. We provide a written estimate before treatment and discuss phased care if appropriate.

Fillings are among the most common dental treatments, but when they’re done well they rely on careful judgement rather than routine work.

A filling repairs a tooth affected by decay, wear, or fracture, restoring strength and function and reducing the risk of further breakdown.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we take a conservative approach, protecting healthy tooth structure and focusing on longevity rather than short-term fixes.

We preserve as much natural tooth as possible.
Materials are chosen to suit the tooth and bite.
Fillings are shaped carefully so they function properly.
We make sure the result is comfortable and easy to keep clean.

Different materials can be used for fillings, and the most suitable choice depends on which tooth is involved, where it sits in the mouth, and the forces it needs to withstand.

We’ll talk through the benefits and limitations of each option, how noticeable it may be, how durable it is likely to be, and any alternatives that may be worth considering.

When is amalgam better than composite?

We consider amalgam when a tooth carries heavy biting forces, when it is difficult to keep the area dry during placement, or when longevity is the main priority. Where appropriate, we bond amalgam to improve strength and the seal.
Mild sensitivity to temperature or biting can last for a few days. Let us know if it continues beyond a week, or if the pain is severe or wakes you at night.

When do you recommend an onlay or crown?

They can restore appearance, support speech and chewing, and help maintain facial structure where teeth have been lost over time.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, dentures are planned carefully, with a focus on comfort, function, and realistic expectations.

Dentures are removable appliances used to replace missing teeth and restore basic function, appearance, and comfort.

They are one of several options for managing tooth loss and can be appropriate in many situations, particularly where fixed solutions are not suitable or preferred. The right approach depends on your oral health, expectations, and day-to-day needs.

Understanding what dentures can realistically provide — and where their limits are — helps you decide whether they fit your life, not just your mouth.
Partial dentures fit around remaining teeth for targeted replacement.
Full dentures replace all teeth in an arch.
Clear explanation of what each option can and can’t do.
Dentures may be suitable for people who have lost several or all of their teeth, particularly where bone levels, medical history, or personal preference make other treatments less appropriate.

They can also be used as a temporary or transitional solution while longer-term options are considered. Suitability is assessed on an individual basis, taking into account comfort, stability, and expected function.
We will discuss alternatives where appropriate so you can make a balanced, informed choice.
Dentures are custom-made prosthetic teeth that sit on the gums and are designed to be removed for cleaning.

They may replace some teeth (partial dentures) or all teeth in one or both jaws (full dentures). Modern dentures are designed to look natural and fit as comfortably as possible, but they remain removable appliances rather than fixed teeth.
Your dentist will explain which type may be appropriate based on your mouth, bite, and existing teeth.
Successful dentures rely on careful planning and accurate fit.

Dentures need daily cleaning and regular checks to keep them fitting well and to protect the health of the gums underneath.

They should be removed for cleaning and usually at night to allow the tissues to rest. Over time, changes in the gums and jaw can affect fit, even if the dentures themselves are undamaged.

Routine reviews help catch small issues early, before comfort or fit becomes a problem.
Wearing dentures usually involves an adjustment period. Speech, eating, and comfort can feel different at first, and it takes time for the mouth and muscles to adapt.

Dentures are designed to improve function, but they do not feel or behave exactly like natural teeth. Regular reviews and adjustments are often needed to maintain comfort as the mouth changes over time.
We guide you through this process and provide advice to help you adapt gradually and comfortably.
Will I be able to eat with dentures?

Eating with dentures usually takes time to adjust. Most people adapt, but certain foods can remain more challenging, especially at first. We provide guidance and review fit to improve comfort and stability.

Dentures are not the only way to replace missing teeth.

Depending on your situation, alternatives such as bridges or dental implants may be discussed.

Each option has benefits and limitations, and we’ll help you weigh these up realistically.

Acrylic dentures are removable dentures made from a lightweight acrylic material and are commonly used to replace missing teeth.

They are often chosen because they are adaptable, cost-effective, and suitable in a wide range of clinical situations. Like all dentures, they involve compromise, and understanding how they function in everyday life is key to deciding whether they are the right option for you.

Before any recommendation is made, we focus on how acrylic dentures would fit your mouth, your expectations, and your day-to-day needs.
Impressions or scans to capture your bite
Wax or printed try-ins to check speech and fit
Tooth shades and shapes selected with you
Relines or soft liners available if gums change
Honest discussion of movement limits vs other materials
Acrylic dentures may be used as a long-term solution or as a temporary step while other treatment options are considered.

They are commonly used when teeth have been lost recently, when bone or gum levels are changing, or when more complex treatments are not suitable. In some cases, they provide a practical way to restore function while keeping future options open.
Your dentist will explain why acrylic dentures are being considered in your particular case.
Acrylic dentures are custom-made dentures constructed primarily from acrylic resin. They can replace some teeth (partial dentures) or all teeth in an upper or lower jaw.
Because acrylic is relatively easy to adjust, these dentures are often used where flexibility is important — for example, when the mouth is still changing or when a simpler solution is appropriate.
They are removable and rely on the shape of the gums, remaining teeth, and muscle control for support.
You’ll know expected timelines, review points, and fees upfront.

Acrylic dentures need daily cleaning to remove plaque and food debris and to protect the health of the gums.

They should be removed for cleaning and usually overnight to allow the tissues to rest. Acrylic can wear or change fit over time as the mouth changes, even if the denture itself appears intact.

Regular reviews help ensure comfort is maintained and allow small adjustments to be made when needed.
Wearing acrylic dentures usually involves an adjustment period. They can feel bulky at first, and eating or speaking may take time to feel natural again.
Over time, many people adapt well, but acrylic dentures do not behave like fixed teeth. Stability and comfort depend on fit, muscle control, and the shape of the supporting tissues.
Follow-up appointments are important to adjust the fit and address any pressure areas as your mouth adapts.
How long do acrylic dentures last?
Acrylic dentures can last for years, but fit and function change as the mouth changes. Relines, repairs, or replacement may be needed over time.
Acrylic dentures can feel bulkier at first, and it takes time to adapt. We adjust the fit and outline what to expect during the settling-in period.
Yes, repairs are often possible if a denture chips or fractures. We’ll explain how to protect them and what to do if damage occurs.
Some patients use a small amount for reassurance, especially for lower dentures. We prioritise fit first and discuss implant support if you want more stability.

Chrome dentures are removable partial dentures made with a thin metal framework that supports replacement teeth.

They are used where precision, stability, and longevity matter — particularly when several natural teeth remain and can help support the denture. Chrome dentures are not simply an upgraded version of acrylic dentures; they are a different design approach with specific advantages and responsibilities.

Understanding how they work, and when they are appropriate, is essential before deciding whether this option suits you.
Detailed assessment of supporting teeth and gums
Framework design to distribute forces evenly
Try-ins to fine-tune speech and smile line
Options for tooth-coloured clasps where suitable

Chrome dentures are typically suitable for people who still have several healthy teeth that can support the framework.
They may not be appropriate where remaining teeth are unstable, heavily restored, or at risk of further loss. In these situations, other options may be more predictable.
We assess the condition of the remaining teeth carefully, as the long-term success of a chrome denture depends on their health.
Chrome dentures use a rigid metal framework, usually made from cobalt chrome, which fits closely around the remaining teeth and gums.

This framework allows the denture to be thinner and more precisely fitted than acrylic alternatives. The design relies on existing teeth for support and stability, using carefully planned clasps or rests.
Because of this precision, chrome dentures require careful planning and accurate impressions to function well.
We map each stage so you know how the framework will feel before you commit.

Compared with acrylic dentures, chrome dentures are generally more rigid and stable.

They tend to feel less bulky in the mouth, but the metal framework does not flex in the same way as acrylic. This rigidity can improve function, but it also means comfort depends heavily on accurate design and the health of the supporting teeth.

Chrome dentures are not always more comfortable by default — the outcome depends on careful assessment and planning.
Chrome dentures are designed to fit precisely and can feel more secure than simpler removable dentures.
However, they are still removable appliances and require an adjustment period. Because the framework is rigid, pressure points can occur if fit or bite changes over time.
Regular reviews are important to ensure comfort and to protect the supporting teeth.
Will metal show when I smile?
We design clasp positions and tooth shades to stay discreet. In some cases we can use tooth-coloured clasps; we’ll show you options before fitting.
Are chrome dentures better than acrylic?

They are different rather than simply better. Chrome frameworks are thinner and more rigid, while acrylic is more flexible. The right choice depends on your remaining teeth, fit needs, and long-term goals.
How long do chrome dentures last?
Chrome frameworks can last for many years, but longevity depends on fit, oral health, and how the supporting teeth change over time. Regular reviews help keep them comfortable.
What if I need more stability later?
We can revisit fit, clasp tension, or consider implant support if you want reduced movement. Any step is planned with your comfort and timeline in mind.

Night guards and occlusal splints are custom-made appliances designed to protect teeth and reduce strain on the jaw.

They’re commonly used where tooth wear, clenching, grinding, or jaw discomfort is present, and where doing nothing may allow problems to progress.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, splints are used thoughtfully — as part of understanding and managing forces, not as a one-size-fits-all solution.
Custom-made appliances designed to protect teeth and reduce strain on the jaw.

Night guards and occlusal splints are used to protect teeth and manage risk when the bite is under strain.

They don’t “cure” grinding or clenching. Their role is more practical than that: to reduce damage, improve comfort, and help keep things stable over time when forces are higher than the teeth can comfortably tolerate.

Used appropriately, they form part of a longer-term management plan rather than a one-off fix.
We’ll take impressions or digital scans to ensure an accurate fit.
We’ll explain how and when to wear it, how to clean it, and what to expect initially.
Review appointments allow us to check comfort, fit, and effectiveness.
When a night guard or splint may be recommended
When a night guard or splint may be recommended
Night guards are often recommended for people who show signs of tooth wear, repeated fractures, jaw discomfort, or muscle tension linked to clenching or grinding.

They’re also used when we see patterns that suggest ongoing risk, even if symptoms are mild. In other words, the decision isn’t based on one sore morning — it’s based on what the teeth and bite are telling us over time.
They are not appropriate for everyone, and they are not a substitute for addressing underlying dental or bite issues where those exist.

Splints are most effective when they’re properly planned and reviewed.

We focus on careful assessment, accurate records, and follow-up to make sure the splint is doing what it’s intended to do. Adjustments may be needed over time as symptoms change or improve.

A splint is not usually a ‘fit once and forget’ device.

A splint is not usually a ‘fit once and forget’ device.

A night guard is a custom-made appliance that fits over the teeth and is usually worn during sleep. Occlusal splints are similar appliances, sometimes designed for more specific bite control or daytime use.
They work by altering how the teeth contact each other and by spreading biting forces more evenly. This can reduce wear, chipping, muscle fatigue, and joint strain.
The design matters. A well-made appliance is planned around your bite, not selected off the shelf.
Wearing a night guard usually involves a short adjustment period. It may feel unfamiliar at first, and some people notice changes in how their bite feels when the appliance is removed in the morning.
The aim is comfort and protection, not forcing the jaw into a new position. We review how the appliance is working and make adjustments if needed.
Used properly, it should feel supportive rather than intrusive.

Night guards are a management tool, not a permanent solution to the cause of grinding.

They need to be checked periodically, as both the appliance and the bite can change over time. Wear on the guard often tells us useful information about ongoing forces.

In some cases, additional treatment or investigation is needed. In others, long-term use of a well-maintained appliance is an effective way of protecting the teeth and supporting comfort.
If you’re unsure whether a night guard or splint is necessary, we encourage you to ask.
Understanding why an appliance has been recommended — and what it can and can’t achieve — is key to making an informed decision.
Will a night guard stop grinding?
A night guard protects the teeth and helps manage damage from grinding, but it does not cure the habit itself. We use it as part of a longer-term management plan.
Are there alternatives if I do not want a splint?
Management may include exercises, habit coaching, or muscle therapies, but a splint is often the safest way to protect teeth and dental work from night-time forces. We will outline all options.
How long will my splint last?
Durability depends on grinding forces, material choice, and care. We monitor wear at reviews and advise when replacement is needed without making fixed promises.
How do I look after the splint?
Rinse and brush it gently after use, store it in a ventilated case, and avoid heat. Bring it to appointments so we can clean and adjust it, especially if your bite changes.
What are the risks or limitations?
Splints can feel tight or cause tenderness if contacts are uneven; adjustments resolve this. Wear or cracks may occur with heavy grinding, so periodic review is important.
Fees reflect the material, lab or in-house production, and the complexity of your bite. We provide a written estimate and discuss phased care if repairs or replacements are anticipated.
Will it affect speech or breathing?
Most people adapt quickly. We refine the fit and thickness to keep speech clear and breathing unobstructed.
When a splint may not be enough
When a splint may not be enough

If tooth wear is advanced, if there are structural issues with the bite, or if symptoms persist, further investigation or treatment may be needed. We’ll explain these findings clearly and discuss appropriate next steps.

Retainers help keep teeth in their corrected positions after orthodontic treatment. Without retention, teeth naturally drift over time, even after a good result. We’ll advise on the most suitable retainer type — removable, fixed, or a combination — based on your bite, alignment and long-term stability needs. We also explain wear schedules, cleaning and what to watch for if a retainer starts to feel tight or loose. Regular checks allow us to confirm fit and function, because retainers can wear or distort gradually. The aim is stable alignment that stays comfortable and easy to maintain.

After teeth are moved, the supporting tissues take time to adapt.

Without retention, small changes can gradually build into noticeable relapse. This isn’t a sign that treatment has ‘failed’ — it’s a normal biological tendency.

Changes in bite and tooth position can continue throughout adult life, not just immediately after orthodontic treatment.

The aim is to maintain stability and reduce the need for repeat treatment later.

Calm, thorough gum care to steady teeth and implants

Gum care focuses on reducing inflammation and protecting the bone and tissues that support your teeth. Gum disease often progresses quietly, with bleeding, bad breath or tenderness as early signs. We assess gum pocket depths, bleeding points and contributing factors such as smoking, medical conditions and bite stress, then recommend care based on your risk level. Treatment may include targeted cleaning below the gum line and guidance on brushing and interdental cleaning that’s realistic to maintain at home. The aim is to stabilise the condition, keep gums comfortable and reduce the chance of long-term problems such as mobility or tooth loss.
Full periodontal assessments with gentle charting and imaging

Plan a clinician-led periodontal gum care review
Stable gums protect your bite and overall health
Gum disease is something we manage over time, not something we “fix” in a single visit.

In practice, the real work is understanding how your gums behave, spotting changes early, and keeping things stable long-term. That means looking at patterns, not reacting to one reading or one bad day.
Periodontal care is about control and consistency. When it’s approached sensibly, most people can keep their gums and teeth functioning well for many years.

Gum disease starts when the gums don’t tolerate plaque as well as they used to.

At first, that often shows up as bleeding or tenderness. Over time, if the irritation continues, the support around the teeth can begin to change. That’s when stability becomes the main concern rather than just appearance or comfort.

Not everyone progresses at the same rate. Some mouths are resilient, others less so. That variation is exactly why careful assessment matters.
We check for bleeding, plaque build-up, and gum measurements
X-rays or scans help us see bone levels where needed
You’ll receive a clear, written plan before any therapy
Bleeding gums, soreness, or bad breath that keeps returning
Gum recession, spacing changes, or teeth feeling slightly mobile
History of smoking, stress, diabetes, or family tendency to gum disease

Non-surgical care first, with clear reviews
Assessing gum health is about context, not just numbers.
We record measurements around each tooth, note where bleeding occurs, and compare findings with previous visits. X-rays are used when they help explain what’s happening below the surface.
What matters most is whether things are stable, drifting, or actively changing. That trend guides sensible decisions far better than isolated figures.
Most patients stabilise with non-surgical care and regular maintenance when we work together on habits and reviews.
Modern hygiene tools with a gentle touch

Ultrasonic scalers, fine hand instruments, and airflow-style finishing help remove plaque and calculus thoroughly. We use numbing gels or local anaesthetic when needed and share measured progress so you feel in control.
Managing gum disease usually starts with improving plaque control and carrying out thorough cleaning where it’s needed.

Sometimes that’s enough. In other cases, more focused treatment is required to reach areas that can’t be kept clean easily. This isn’t about escalation for its own sake — it’s about choosing the level of intervention that matches the level of risk.
The aim is to bring the condition under control and keep it there.
Answers to common gum care questions
Treatment is planned gently with numbing gels or local anaesthetic where needed. You’ll be guided on what to expect and how to keep things comfortable afterwards.
How long does it take to see improvement?
Gums often look and feel healthier within weeks, but long-term stability depends on regular maintenance and the risk factors we identify together.
Inflammation can reduce and pockets can tighten with good care. Recession usually needs protective maintenance rather than regrowth, and we’ll discuss options if grafting or referral is appropriate.
What about implants with gum inflammation?
Peri-implant tissues can often be stabilised with careful cleaning, airflow-style stain removal, and close reviews. If advanced peri-implantitis is present, we’ll outline referral options calmly.

Tooth wear refers to the gradual loss of tooth structure over time.

It’s a common issue and often develops slowly, meaning many people don’t notice it until changes in shape, sensitivity, or appearance become more obvious.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, tooth wear is managed thoughtfully, with an emphasis on understanding why it’s happening before deciding how to treat it.
Tooth wear refers to the gradual loss of tooth structure over time
It often develops slowly before changes become more obvious
Care focuses on understanding why it’s happening before deciding how to treat it
Factors contributing to tooth wear can include acidic foods or drinks, reflux, dry mouth, clenching or grinding, bite relationships, and lifestyle habits
Often, tooth wear results from a combination of influences rather than a single cause
Tooth wear can occur for different reasons
Erosion is caused by acids softening the tooth surface
Attrition is wear from tooth-to-tooth contact, often linked to clenching or grinding
Abrasion involves mechanical wear, such as from brushing habits
More than one type of wear is often present at the same time

Understanding the cause and pattern of wear helps guide appropriate management.

Assessment may include examining how teeth meet, looking for signs of muscle activity, reviewing diet and habits, and checking for changes over time.

Not all wear requires immediate treatment, but monitoring is important.
This may include monitoring, protective appliances such as night guards, dietary advice, and targeted dental treatment where appropriate.
Often, more than one measure is used together, depending on how wear is progressing
The aim is to slow or stop progression before considering restorative treatment

If tooth wear is advanced or causing functional or comfort issues, treatment may be discussed.

Options can range from simple protective measures to restorative approaches designed to rebuild worn surfaces.

Any proposed treatment is planned carefully and staged where possible.
Treatment is considered when wear affects comfort or function
Options range from protective measures to restorations
Plans are staged and tailored to the individual

Tooth wear is usually a long-term consideration rather than a quick fix.

Ongoing review helps ensure that teeth remain comfortable and functional, and that any intervention remains appropriate as circumstances change.

Do I need a consultation before any treatment?

Are therapeutic injectables the same as cosmetic toxin treatments?
No. Here they are used for symptom relief in carefully selected muscles, not for cosmetic aims. Doses, targets, and follow-up are chosen for function and comfort.
What if conservative steps are enough?
If self-care, guards, or physiotherapy resolve symptoms, we continue monitoring without injectables. Medicine is only added when clinically beneficial.
When should I seek urgent care?

Anti-wrinkle treatments are used to soften the appearance of certain facial lines by temporarily relaxing specific muscles that contribute to them over time.

These treatments are medical procedures and should be approached carefully. A thorough consultation is essential to assess suitability, discuss expectations, and explain how treatment works.

Our focus is on subtle, natural-looking outcomes that respect facial balance rather than dramatic change.

Anti-wrinkle treatments do not treat all types of facial lines and will not replace skin care, volume treatments, or surgical options where these are more appropriate.

As with any medical procedure, there are risks and possible side effects. These are discussed in full during consultation.

Suitability depends on individual facial anatomy, medical history, and personal goals.
Anti-wrinkle treatments may not be appropriate for everyone. Certain medical conditions, medications, or life stages can affect whether treatment is advised.
We carry out a full medical consultation before recommending any treatment and will advise honestly if it is not suitable — including when doing nothing is the better option.
Anti-wrinkle treatments work by reducing muscle activity in targeted areas of the face. This can soften lines that form through repeated facial movement.
The effect is temporary and develops gradually over several days. Treatment does not stop the ageing process, but it can soften the appearance of certain lines for a limited period.
Your practitioner will explain which areas may benefit and what level of change is realistic.
Results are temporary and depend on your response. We avoid high doses or rushed top-ups to protect facial function.
Mapped injection points for balanced results

We plan doses per muscle group, favouring multiple micro-injections to distribute medicine evenly. Needle gauge and depth are chosen to respect underlying vessels and avoid diffusion into unintended areas.
Clear guidance and prompt escalation routes
Treatment appointments are typically brief and involve carefully placed injections in specific facial muscles.
Results are not immediate and usually develop over several days. Effects are temporary and gradually wear off, meaning repeat treatment may be required to maintain the result.
We explain the process, aftercare, and potential risks before treatment begins so you can make an informed decision.
Results develop gradually and wear off over time. The duration varies between individuals, and we discuss realistic expectations during consultation.
Our approach focuses on careful assessment and conservative dosing. The aim is a softer appearance while maintaining natural facial movement.
Most patients report brief pinpricks. Topical anaesthetic can be provided if needed, and we use fine needles to reduce discomfort.
Can I combine this with other treatments?
We often stage anti-wrinkle care with fillers, skin boosters, or polynucleotides when suitable. Sequencing is planned in consultation to keep safety first.
What if I decide not to continue?
Results wear off over time. We document doses so future care can be paused or adjusted without pressure.

How are boosters different from fillers?
Boosters are runnier, hydrating injectables that improve skin texture rather than adding volume. We avoid mixing them with volume-driven fillers in the same plane.
Most patients notice improved hydration and suppleness after the first sessions, with further gains after the second or third treatment.
Can they be combined with anti-wrinkle care?
Often yes, when staged safely. We sequence treatments so skin can settle and prescription medicines remain effective.
What if I have sensitive skin?
We assess barrier health first. If skin is inflamed or compromised, we may delay boosters and focus on repair before proceeding.
Maintenance varies but top-ups are often recommended every few months once the initial course is complete.

Protect teeth from sport, grinding, or post-orthodontic movement

Mouthguards and retainers have different jobs, but both rely on precise fit to work properly. A custom mouthguard protects teeth and soft tissues during sport by distributing impact forces, while a retainer helps maintain tooth position after orthodontic treatment. We assess your bite, lifestyle needs and any existing dental work, then use impressions or digital scans to create an appliance that’s secure, comfortable and easy to clean. Regular review matters because appliances can wear, distort or stop fitting well as teeth change. The aim is predictable protection and long-term stability, not a quick off-the-shelf compromise.

How long do guards or retainers last?
Longevity depends on wear and bite forces. We will show you how to spot thinning or cracks and advise when to replace or adjust.
Can I choose between lab-made and 3D printed?
Yes. We recommend the material based on durability, comfort, and how your bite loads the device, then confirm your preference.
How do I clean and store them?
Use lukewarm water, non-abrasive cleaning aids, and a ventilated case. Avoid hot water or harsh chemicals that distort the fit.
What if my retainer feels tight?
Mild tightness after a break can be normal. If pressure is painful or teeth have shifted, contact us for a review before continuing.

Retainers help keep teeth in their corrected positions after orthodontic treatment. Without retention, teeth naturally drift over time, even after a good result. We’ll advise on the most suitable retainer type — removable, fixed, or a combination — based on your bite, alignment and long-term stability needs. We also explain wear schedules, cleaning and what to watch for if a retainer starts to feel tight or loose. After teeth are moved, the supporting tissues take time to adapt.

The aim is to maintain stability and reduce the need for repeat treatment later.

Missing teeth can change how you eat, speak and smile — and it’s not always obvious what the “right” solution is. At St Mary’s House Dental Care, implant care is clinician-led and planning-heavy: we focus on getting the foundations right so you can make a confident decision.

We’ll talk you through options (implants, bridges, dentures — or sometimes “do nothing yet”), explain the trade-offs, and recommend what’s sensible for your mouth, your health, and your long-term maintenance.
Fixed tooth replacement for suitable patients
Clear options and costs explained upfront
Local care in Shoreham-by-Sea, near Brighton
Clinician-led, planning-first — We prioritise diagnosis, stability and long-term maintenance, not rushed sales dentistry.
Digital assessment where appropriate — Scans and 3D planning can help us assess bone, bite and space, and reduce uncertainty.
Guided surgery where appropriate — When suitable, we design and 3D print surgical guides to help transfer the plan accurately to the mouth.
Clear, transparent care — We explain benefits, risks and alternatives, and give you time to decide.
Local follow-up and aftercare — Implant health is a long game, and reviews plus hygiene support matter.

Dental implants can be a suitable option for many people — but they are not a “one size fits all” treatment. Outcomes depend on bone levels, gum health, bite forces, space, and the position of neighbouring teeth.

Our approach is to plan the tooth first and the implant second. Where appropriate, we use 3D imaging and digital planning to choose implant position and angulation that supports a cleanable, well-supported final crown.
Design for cleaning and long-term gum health
Consider bite forces, not just appearance

A dental implant is a small post placed into the jawbone to act as a replacement tooth root. Once healed, it supports a restoration — commonly a crown for a single tooth, or a bridge or denture solution for multiple teeth.

Implant treatment is usually staged and depends on healing. We’ll explain what’s involved and what alternatives might suit you better.
When implants can be a good option — If you have one or more missing teeth and want a fixed solution, implants may be suitable after assessment.
Bone and gum health matters — Healthy gums and adequate bone are important. If bone is reduced, grafting may sometimes be considered.
Medical factors — Some medical conditions and medications can affect healing. We’ll take a full history and advise safely.
Smoking and maintenance — Smoking and inconsistent cleaning can increase risk. We’ll be honest about what improves success.
Alternatives are sometimes better — In some mouths, a bridge, denture, or a short period of monitoring may be the better choice.
1) Consultation & assessment — We examine your teeth and gums, discuss your goals, and check suitability. Scans may be advised.
2) Planning — If proceeding, we plan tooth position, implant placement and timings. You’ll receive a clear treatment outline.
3) Implant placement — The implant is placed under local anaesthetic (and sedation options may be discussed where appropriate).
4) Healing phase — Healing time varies. We’ll guide you on what to expect and how to look after the area.
5) Final restoration — Once stable, we fit the crown or bridge and check bite, appearance and cleanability.
6) Reviews & maintenance — Long-term health depends on cleaning and regular reviews — we’ll support you with both.
Timelines vary. Healing time, bone quality, and your medical history guide whether we stage treatment or move more quickly.
Digital and 3D dentistry for implant care

Where appropriate, we use digital scans and 3D planning to assess space, bone and bite, and to design implant placement with the final tooth in mind. We also design and 3D print surgical guides to help position implants accurately according to the plan.

Digital tools don’t replace clinical judgement — but used well, they can reduce uncertainty and improve communication.
Fixed, natural feel — Implants can feel closer to natural teeth than removable options, for suitable cases.
No need to prepare neighbouring teeth — A single implant crown doesn’t usually require shaping adjacent teeth (unlike some bridge designs).
Supports bone and function — Replacing a missing root can help maintain function; we’ll explain what’s realistic for your case.
Designed for cleaning — We plan restorations to be maintainable, because “looks great” isn’t enough without long-term health.
Clear, honest planning — We explain risks, alternatives, and maintenance so you can decide with confidence.
Cleaning is non-negotiable — Implants need daily cleaning just like teeth, sometimes with specific brushes or interdental aids.
Regular reviews — We monitor gums, bite and implant stability over time and act early if anything changes.
Hygiene support — Professional cleaning and coaching can protect long-term implant health.
Lifestyle factors — Smoking and uncontrolled gum disease increase risk — we’ll help you reduce avoidable problems.
Are dental implants right for everyone?
Not always. Suitability depends on gum health, bone levels, bite forces, medical history and maintenance. We confirm this after assessment.
Implant placement is usually done with local anaesthetic. Most people describe post-treatment soreness rather than “pain”. We’ll explain what to expect and how we manage comfort.
Timings vary. Some cases need staged healing or additional procedures. We’ll give you a realistic timeline once we’ve assessed you.
Many implants function well for a long time, but outcomes depend on factors like cleaning, gum health, smoking, bite forces and general health. We’ll discuss risks and maintenance honestly.
What if I don’t have enough bone?
Reduced bone doesn’t automatically rule implants out. In some cases, bone grafting may be considered. We’ll explain whether it’s appropriate and the trade-offs.
What are the alternatives to implants?
Depending on your mouth, options may include bridges, dentures, or sometimes doing nothing for a period. We’ll compare pros and cons so you can choose confidently.
Costs depend on complexity and the type of restoration. After assessment, we’ll provide clear options and fees so you can decide without pressure.
Implant care at St Mary’s House — clinician-led

Dr Nick Maxwell leads implant planning and placement at St Mary’s House Dental Care. He holds an MSc in Restorative & Aesthetic Dentistry and a PGDip in Orthodontics & Facial Orthopaedics, and has completed implant surgical training including intensive implant placement training in Cairo (2014).

He also designs and 3D prints surgical guides for guided implant placement, combining clinical judgement with digital planning where appropriate. The focus is careful case selection, clear communication, and long-term maintainability.

Prevention-first dentistry that keeps teeth for life

Preventative and general dentistry is about keeping problems small — or avoiding them altogether. A thorough check-up looks at teeth, gums, bite and soft tissues, alongside any symptoms or changes you’ve noticed. These visits help us spot early decay, gum inflammation and tooth wear before they become more complex to manage. Advice is tailored to your risk factors rather than generic rules, including daily cleaning technique, fluoride use, diet and habits that affect enamel and gum health. Where simple treatment is needed, we plan it carefully to keep teeth comfortable and easy to maintain, and we agree review intervals that suit your needs.

Fillings are among the most common dental treatments, but when they’re done well they rely on careful judgement rather than routine work.

A filling repairs a tooth affected by decay, wear, or fracture, restoring strength and function and reducing the risk of further breakdown.

At St Mary’s House Dental Care, we take a conservative approach, protecting healthy tooth structure and focusing on longevity rather than short-term fixes.
Conservative repair of decay, wear, or fracture
Materials matched to tooth and bite
Careful shaping for comfort and function
Good fillings are about more than just filling a hole.
We preserve as much natural tooth as possible.
Materials are chosen to suit the tooth and bite.
Fillings are shaped carefully so they function properly.
We make sure the result is comfortable and easy to keep clean.

Different materials can be used for fillings, and the most suitable choice depends on which tooth is involved, where it sits in the mouth, and the forces it needs to withstand.

We’ll talk through the benefits and limitations of each option, how noticeable it may be, how durable it is likely to be, and any alternatives that may be worth considering.
We match material choice to the tooth and bite
We discuss appearance and durability clearly
We explain any alternatives where relevant
A filling may be recommended if decay has weakened part of a tooth, an old filling has failed or leaked, a tooth has chipped or worn down, or sensitivity suggests early damage.
Some patients come to us in Shoreham-by-Sea unsure whether a filling is really needed.
Not every small defect needs immediate treatment.
Where appropriate, we’ll discuss monitoring versus intervention so you can make an informed decision.
Placing a filling is usually straightforward.
Modern techniques allow fillings to be placed comfortably for most patients.
After treatment, it’s normal to notice mild sensitivity for a short time.
We’ll explain what’s expected, how to look after the tooth, and when to let us know if something doesn’t feel right.
When a filling may not be enough

A filling is not always the most reliable long-term option, particularly when a tooth has been significantly weakened.

If that applies, we may discuss options such as an onlay or crown, and explain the reasons clearly so you understand the trade-offs involved.
We explain when a crown or onlay may be safer
We discuss trade-offs so you can decide confidently
When a filling needs extra support
If the tooth is heavily broken down or the nerve is affected, we guide you through the next restorative steps.

Regular hygiene visits and good gum care help keep the margins clean and reduce the risk of new decay developing around a filling.

We set maintenance intervals based on gum health, any clenching or grinding, and diet-related risks.
Hygiene and gum care to protect the edges
Monitoring for cracks, leakage, or wear
Occlusal splints for clenching or grinding
Check-ups to time replacements before problems escalate
Advice on diet and home care around restorations
When is amalgam better than composite?

We consider amalgam when a tooth carries heavy biting forces, when it is difficult to keep the area dry during placement, or when longevity is the main priority. Where appropriate, we bond amalgam to improve strength and the seal.
Mild sensitivity to temperature or biting can last for a few days. Let us know if it continues beyond a week, or if the pain is severe or wakes you at night.
We numb the tooth where needed, isolate it, remove decay or any failing material, then place and bond the filling. We shape and polish it carefully and check your bite before you leave.
When do you recommend an onlay or crown?
If there isn’t enough healthy tooth left for a filling to hold securely, we may recommend an onlay or crown to support the tooth and create a more reliable seal.
Contact us to discuss whether a filling is the right option for you.
